title: coalition considers contingency plans for energy rationing
story: A Government energy security review, due this summer, is likely to list the possibility of State-owned liquefied natural gas storage being developed to facilitate the delivery of reserve supplies. Photograph: Christopher FurlongGetty Images The Government is discussing contingency plans with industry to organise energy rationing if the Ukraine war leads to an interruption in supplies of Russian oil and gas into European markets. The talks, acknowledged by three people briefed on the situation, have centred on concerns about the stability of winter supplies this year if there is no end to the Russian invasion and western sanctions against the Kremlin escalate. â€œItâ€™s very clear that itâ€™s a sensitive situation at the moment because of the war,â€ said an informed source. â€œThere are meetings taking place. There are contingency plans that have always been there. Theyâ€™re being dusted down to see if they need to be updated.â€One question under discussion is the prospect of keeping the coal-fired power station at Moneypoint open for up to three years beyond its scheduled 2025 closure while waiting for new gas-fired electricity generation to come on stream. Such a move would undercut efforts to curtail carbon emissions but is increasingly seen as a step that may be necessary to boost reserve generation capacity. The talks come as Russian president Vladimir Putin raised the stakes in the confrontation by signing a decree to halt supply contracts with â€œunfriendly countiesâ€ if they do not pay in roubles from Friday. Big European buyers such as Germany have been refusing to pay in roubles for fear of weakening the impact of sanctions and strengthening the Russian currency. Ireland imports some 75 per cent of its gas, with the bulk of those supplies coming from Norway via the British network and only a small proportion originating in Russia. Although senior figures with knowledge of the talks said that factor provides a good degree of protection to energy supplies in the short term, there was concern even before the Putin decree of Thursday that the situation could spiral beyond control if the war is not settled.Last-resort stepsPeople familiar with the talks in Dublin said the invasion has led senior officials to discuss last-resort steps with industry to decide on the allocation of electricity and gas supplies if the energy flow is interrupted or pricing reaches unsustainable levels.Although hospitals and schools would be a top priority, one business figure said the question of maintaining food supply-chain connectivity had emerged as a big issue because of pressures on the international food supply chain. A Government energy security review, due this summer, is likely to list the possibility of State-owned liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage being developed to facilitate the delivery of reserve supplies, it is understood. Global leaders want to increase LNG imports from the US into Europe to offset demand for Russian energy. But it remains unclear whether Ireland could acquire temporary seaborne storage before building any infrastructure.

title: schools struggle to keep classes open in latest coronavirus wave
story: Enda Oâ€™Gorman, principal of Mother of Hope National School, Littlepace, Dublin 15. Photograph: Alan BetsonThe  Last week school principal Enda McGorman received word that four of his teachers were out for Covid reasons. The following morning, the number had doubled to eight.â€œThis is every bit as bad as it was last January and December, if not worse,â€ says McGorman, principal of Mother of Hope National School, Littlepace in Dublin 15.This week the 450-pupil school had a third of staff out of action. As a result, it had to ert support teachers for special needs pupils into mainstream teaching roles to prevent classes being sent home.The school, like many others across the State, has struggling to keep its doors open during the latest Covid wave. But the rolling nature of school disruption is raising fresh concerns over the long-term scale of learning loss among pupils.â€œThis feels different,â€ says McGorman. â€œThe repeated disruption is massively damaging for schools and pupils . . . weâ€™re seeing staff getting repeat infections now. As soon as some recover, others are off.â€œAt least during the winter we had substitute teachers available to us. Now, they are back in college or on placement, where theyâ€™re not available to work as substitutes. Even the substitute panel of teachers, which is supposed to provide cover, has been hit by Covid.â€McGorman says the scale of learning loss after three years of disruption is now emerging as a major source of concern.â€œWeâ€™re seeing it right across the board: they lost out on learning in the curriculum, general knowledge, fine motor skills, gross motor skills, handwriting . . . itâ€™s right across the board. You even see it watching then playing soccer, with legs flailing around the places . . . we really have a job of work to make up those losses.â€Nationally, there appears to be a similar picture.PÃ¡iric Clerkin of the Irish Primary Principalsâ€™ Network says that while Covid is not making headlines, the disruption in schools is very real.â€œSchools are under the exact same pressure as were during the height of the crisis,â€ says Clerkin.The exact scale of learning loss in Irish schools had yet to be quantified. Results of last yearâ€™s standardised tests at primary level â€“ due later this year â€“ should give the first sense of how far children are lagging behind.However, research elsewhere gives a clue over the scale of losses. In the UK, a survey of teachers and school leaders found that students were roughly three months behind by last July. The Office for Standards in Education found that younger students had regressed to the point where some forgot how to hold a pencil.Learning lossesIn the Netherlands, an April 2021 study found that primary school students performed on average 20 per cent worse on tests than the equivalent cohorts had for the three years before the pandemic. Among students from disadvantaged families, learning losses tended to be even greater, up to 60 per cent larger than for the general population.Both countries have spent billions on tutoring, counselling and summer programmes for children, but that extra support has not yet caught them up. Disadvantaged students and those with special needs have fared worst.In Ireland, Minister for Education Nora Foley has pointed to the Covid Learning and Support Scheme which aims to help schools mitigate the adverse impacts of Covid-19 on student learning loss.She said up to â‚¬52 million in extra teaching hours for schools has been made available during the current school year. Enhanced allocations are provided for schools with Deis, or disadvantaged, status.McGorman, however, says his school has been unable to access extra teaching hours due to a crisis in substitution cover.â€œAny substitutes staff we can get our hands on are being used to plug holes. We just donâ€™t have access to teaches to run it,â€ he says.He is unsure if the school will be able to bank the hours it was entitled to, or if the school will lose them at the end of the academic year.â€œWhat we really need is longer-term planning. All these initiatives are happening too late, and then we canâ€™t find the teaching staff to run them.â€Everything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreak

title: huge question mark looms over ireland s energy security
story: Delaying the scheduled closure of the coal-fired power station at Moneypoint is among the measures under consideration. Photograph: Neil WarnerVladimir Putinâ€™s war on Ukraine has already led to surging prices for gas, oil, motor fuel and power since the invasion began in February. Now questions are being raised about the security of supplies as the threat of more western sanctions against the Kremlin and a row over payments cast uncertainty over imports of Russian energy.As if there was any doubt about the intensity of the energy market shock set off by the military campaign, German moves to activate the first phase of an emergency plan that could lead to gas rationing are salutary. The development comes in spite of chancellor Olaf Scholzâ€™s opposition to an EU ban on oil and gas from Russia. That stance will be tested again and again in coming weeks if the Russians dig in for the long haul in Ukraine and there is no deal to end the conflict. Putin is using energy as a lever by insisting on payments for energy in roubles, something western buyers wonâ€™t accept because it would dim the impact of financial sanctions and boost the Russian currency.Taoiseach MicheÃ¡l Martin was at pains to stress in an RTÃ‰ interview on Thursday that he did not speak of winter fuel shortages when he addressed the Fianna FÃ¡il parliamentary party on Wednesday evening. â€œI simply said that energy security is something we have to focus on and prepare for over the next winter period,â€ Mr Martin said.FalloutThis question ranks high on the agenda in talks between officials and industry on the fallout from war. Concern has been raised in such engagements, constant since the invasion began, about the stability of supplies next winter when domestic demand for gas and electricity is at its highest and the full brunt of any interruption to Russian supplies would hit markets. That in turn has led people to dust down contingency plans that deal with supply priorities if energy has to be rationed in Ireland.â€œItâ€™s happening in real time,â€ said one energy industry figure with knowledge of the talks. â€œItâ€™s a normal part of looking ahead, looking around the corner at what would need to be done.â€Measures discussed to mitigate any supply crunch include the prospect of delaying the 2025 scheduled closure of the giant coal-fired power station at Moneypoint, where the ESB has already resolved to stop using Russian coal in favour of Colombian supplies. People familiar with the discussions are quick to acknowledge that such a move would blunt efforts to reach climate targets, yet the war has changed the debate. â€œClimate is rather important but the security of supply trumps it,â€ the energy figure said. Another person, familiar with the thinking in the Coalition, said: â€œNobody wants to be in this space.â€Liquefied natural gasAnother option under examination is the development of some State-owned liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage capacity. Such an initiative would be separate to plans by the privately-owned US group New Fortress Energy to build a â‚¬650 million LNG plant in Co Kerry, which have raised the hackles of the Greens and environmentalists. That plan is before An Bord PleanÃ¡la with a decision due in September, but Government policy is opposed to imports of fracked gas.For all that, there is some confidence in industry and official circles that a short-term gas supply crunch can be avoided. The reason for that is the source of Irish supplies, a quarter of which come from the domestic Corrib field on the western coast while the remainder is imported on pipelines into Northern Ireland from Britain, which takes much of its supply from Norway. Although the current proportion of Russian gas supplies into Britain is said to be about 6per cent, a senior business person said it would not take much of an interruption to Russian supplies to distort the UK market at a time of higher seasonal demand for gas.Still, the lesson learned in the weeks since Russian tanks stormed Ukraine is prices can rise rapidly even when gas and oil continue to flow through pipelines. title: ireland takes to its feet for climb with charlie bird
story: Charlie Bird  trains for his Croagh Patrick climb: While Bird will lead hundreds up the famed pilgrimage route on Croagh Patrick, many more have organised their own treks in  support for his struggle with motor neurone disease. Photograph: Maxwells From the Donegal highlands, to the drumlins of Cavan and onto the rocky headlands of Cork, Ireland is taking to its feet this weekend as thousands countrywide prepare to pull on their hiking boots with Charlie Bird. â€œI have no idea how many people are going to scale the Reek with me, but I feel it is going to be a day like no other,â€ he says. While Bird will lead hundreds up the famed pilgrimage route on Croagh Patrick, many more have organised their own treks in a national outpouring of support for his struggle with motor neurone disease (MND).Fundraisers â€“ as far away as Australia, North America and the United Arab Emirates â€“ are expected to take in more than â‚¬1 million by the time the first boots stomp on Saturday for the Climb with Charlie challenge. The money will go to the Irish Motor Neurone Disease Association and suicide charity Pieta. Like countless others, Kathleen Gill, of Clonmany, Co Donegal, was so moved by Birdâ€™s disclosure of his diagnosis and determination on the Late Late Show, that she organised a climb of the 494m high Cnoc Bulaba, towering over the Inishowen village. Gill was determined to pay tribute to her uncle Jimmy Harkin, who died of MND at the age of 49 in 2009, and who always scaled Bulaba on his frequent trips home from Birmingham. â€œWhen we watched Charlie Bird being interviewed on the Late Late, it brought it all back,â€ she says, â€œhow horrific the diagnosis is.â€ â€œWhen it affects your own family you can immediately relate to it, you know the journey he is on.â€Harkin, the youngest of 10 children, was a â€œfantastic character, very jovial, and a great singerâ€, says Gill. â€œLike Charlie, he dealt with his diagnosis very courageously and kept a positive front. We all prayed for a miracle but it just wasnâ€™t to be.â€œIt will be very emotional for everybody on the day, and also to watch Charlie, who has been very open and honest about how he is dealing with it. It is lovely to know he is getting strength from the show of support and solidarity,â€ says Gill. With two days to go before the climb we have now raised almost Eight Hundred and Fifty thousand Euro and I think we will go beyond our target of ONE million euro. Thanks to everyone for extending the hand of friendship. I am overwhelmed by what is happening. Thanks ğŸ™â€” Charlie Bird (@charliebird49) â€œI think it is also very symbolic. Motor neurone is a climb you have to keep going.â€Nationwide challengesOriginally from Kildare, SiobhÃ¡n Bennett, now living in Connemara, organised one of the most challenging climbs planned, the 700m high Ben Gorm overlooking Killary fjord in Co Mayo. Some 50 climbers will partake in the trek expected to take three-six hours. â€œIt is not easy by any means,â€ says Bennett. â€œBut the views are stunning. â€œIt has got the imagination of people. The fact that Charlieâ€™s voice is going â€“ the voice we always knew from when we were very littleâ€¦â€ she trails off. â€œI think everyone has a Charlie Bird memory.â€In Co Louth, Craig Ballentine is making final preparations for a 6km night-time trek from Glenmore to Barnavave peak (350m), illuminated with 100 torches. Climbers will â€œwatch the sunset, then admire the stars and views over Carlingford, Dundalk Bay and down to Malahideâ€, he says. Pitched as â€œwalk and talk therapyâ€, the 8pm start â€“ â€œwhen people are biologically more relaxedâ€ â€“ will allow more than 20 climbers to open up about their own experiences with MND and mental health issues. With the mental health crisis after the pandemic, the success of Climb with Charlie has shown the country at its best, he adds. â€œThis is Ireland sticking together and helping each other.â€ Ursula Oâ€™Kennedy will be among about 20 Irish expatriates trekking up Mount Cooke in Western Australia as much of Ireland sleeps. Based in Perth, the Newry-born special needs teacher said Birdâ€™s story and positivity galvanised her and husband Aidan, from Galway, to plan the 17.5km trek. â€œIt is the least we can do. He has done so much for us all over the years.â€œIt will be the middle of the night at home. I reckon we will be the first to finish on the day, unless Sydney gets ahead of us,â€ says Oâ€™Kennedy. Temperatures will range between seven degrees in the east and about 10 degrees in the west â€œand as we climb of course it will be colder. So layer up and bring a rain jacketâ€.Paul Allen, a public relations consultant and former colleague of Bird, co-ordinating the treks, says they are â€œnearly afraid to speculateâ€ on numbers that will turn out on the day. Such is its success, the organisers have switched mode to warning those not able for the challenge not to put themselves at risk. â€œPeople can walk in their local area, or on the beach. It doesnâ€™t have to be a situation where people are endangering themselves,â€ says Allen. Bird will be joined by 500 â€œfriends and familyâ€ including wife Claire, daughters Orla and Neasa, and five grandchildren, as well as singer Daniel Oâ€™Donnell, Matt Molloy of the Chieftains, boxer Barry McGuigan on the 2Â½-hour trek up and down Croagh Patrick, with plans to live-stream it online. Once atop the Reek, Bird will light five candles, for Ukraine, those suffering terminal illness as well as loved ones. A local pipe band will play on the mountain.At the peak, where he will make remarks through a voice app, he will also light a candle for friend and cervical cancer campaigner Vicky Phelan. â€œVicky had hoped to be at the bottom of Croagh Patrick to wave us all off,â€ he says. â€œUnfortunately, because of her current health situation she canâ€™t make it, but some of her family will be with us for the climb.â€Bird says he â€œwould love people on top of Croagh Patrick to have a minute of silence for the people of Ukraine as wellâ€.â€œI have one goal left on my own bucket list and that is to continue to extend the hand of friendship while I can,â€ he adds. title: scepticism about plans to make social media directors liable for allowing harm
story: Minister for Culture and Media Catherine Martin. Photograph: Dara Mac DÃ³naillSenior figures in Government have privately expressed scepticism about plans to make directors of social media companies personally criminally liable for content on their platforms.The plans were discussed on Wednesday by Minister for Culture and Media Catherine Martin and Fianna FÃ¡il Senators.Speaking on condition of anonymity, several senior Government figures said they thought the prospect of senior executives in social media companies being jailed was remote, and they expected the draft legislation would not be significantly toughened during the legislative process.But Fianna FÃ¡il Senator Malcolm Byrne, who has championed efforts to strengthen the Bill, said the â€œgoal is not to have a load of prosecutions â€“ itâ€™s to change the culture of these companiesâ€.Mr Byrne and fellow Senator Shane Cassells met Ms Martin to discuss proposed amendments which would toughen the planned online safety Bill, published by Ms Martinâ€™s department in January.While the Ministerâ€™s spokesman pointed out there is already a provision of the Bill which could be used to extend criminal liability to directors of social media companies, the amendments proposed by the Senators would make a prosecution much easier and more likely.Under the current draft, social media company directors could be prosecuted, but only when they have ignored specific instructions from the new Media Commission. Changes proposed by the Fianna FÃ¡il Senators would make it possible to prosecute directors if they knowingly or recklessly allowed their platforms to be used for online harm.Ms Martin told the Senators she was happy to consider amendments and work with them to achieve a shared goal.Mr Byrne said the draft legislation â€œis nowhere near as strong as it needs to beâ€. He said if the algorithms used by social media companies deliberately directed people to harmful content â€“ he cited the example of girls being directed to sites which promoted eating disorders â€“ then the directors should be criminally liable.Spokespersons for Facebook and Twitter declined to comment.The Ministerâ€™s spokesman said she would like to see the Bill enacted before the summer recess. He declined to give details of any meetings that Ms Martin had with the social media giants on the Bill, but the lobbying register shows she was lobbied by both Twitter and Facebook.The social media giants are expected to strongly oppose the director liability measures in the Bill. Sources say they are likely to press the case with the Government that such provisions would harm Irelandâ€™s image among tech companies as a destination for inward investment. Many of the worldâ€™s leading tech companies have European headquarters in Dublin, and pay hundreds of millions of euro in corporation tax to the Irish exchequer every year.

title: review reminds of european security if britain pivots to indo pacific
story: Britainâ€™s shadow foreign secretary David Lammy: â€˜We need to put past Brexit isions behind us, stop seeking rows with European partners and use this moment to explore new ways to rebuild relations with European allies through a new UK-EU security pact.â€™ Photograph: Hollie AdamsGetty The war in Ukraine has created a distraction from Boris Johnsonâ€™s domestic political troubles and given him an opportunity to play a role on the global stage. But it has also raised questions about Britainâ€™s national security strategy as it was laid out in an Integrated Review of Defence, Security, Development and Foreign Policy almost exactly a year ago.The review identified Russia as the â€œmost acute, direct threatâ€ to Britain but it called for a tilt towards the Indo-Pacific and suggested that the future would belong to ad hoc coalitions of the willing rather than formal alliances or multilateral organisations. It said that a post-Brexit â€œGlobal Britainâ€ could become â€œthe European partner with the broadest and most integrated presence in the Indo- Pacificâ€.Britain would remain committed to European defence as part of Nato at the same time as it once again projected military power east of Suez. It would do this with a small navy, a diminishing air force and a shrinking army that will soon be down to 72,500.In a new paper (https:rusi.orgexplore-our-researchpublicationscommentaryuks-integrated-review-one-year-fit-purpose)for the Royal United Services Institute (Rusi), its director of military sciences, Paul Oâ€™Neill, notes that the politics of last year did not allow the Integrated Review to acknowledge the European Unionâ€™s importance to collective security.Military capabilityâ€œWhile Natoâ€™s military capability dwarfs that of the EU, the EU controls vital mechanisms allowing that capability to be used â€“ such as the regulatory framework permitting the movement of people, ammunition and equipment, and the infrastructure specifications for roads, bridges and so on â€“ while the new strategic compass is intended to enhance the EUâ€™s defence potential. Moreover, the defence command paper fails to provide a clear line between the threat (Russia) and the defence response. Reductions in conventional capabilities are coupled with plans for both the navy and army to spend more time persistently engaged outside Europe in pursuit of a still-undefined â€˜Global Britainâ€™ chimera,â€ he says.In a speech at Tufts University in Massachusetts on Thursday, Labourâ€™s shadow foreign secretary, David Lammy, said Britain could play a leading role in the debate about the future of European security. But it could only do so if it put behind it what he called the â€œpetty&nbspdiplomatic spatsâ€ Johnsonâ€™s government was pursuing to serve short-term, domestic political interests.Defence cutsâ€œAs war ravages parts of our continent we need to put past Brexit isions behind us, stop seeking rows with European partners and use this moment to explore new ways to rebuild relations with European allies through a new UK-EU security pact.â€Lammy called for the Integrated Review to be revisited to ensure that the Indo-Pacific tilt should not come at the cost of European security. And he called for defence cuts to be reversed, a plea that will find support among hawkish Conservative MPs who want Britain to increase defence spending to ensure that Germany does not surpass it as the biggest European contributor to Nato.Rishi Sunak refused to increase defence spending in last weekâ€™s Spring Statement and Britainâ€™s economic circumstances are set to get worse, with sluggish growth forecast to fall further in the next few years. Oâ€™Neill argues that throwing money at the armed forces is not a solution and that absorbing a sudden infusion of cash would create problems of its own.â€œAt its core, any new strategy needs a focus on deterrence and defence of the Euro-Atlantic area, in which the UK works with and not in competition against its allies and partners. While more money is needed, this must be more than a sudden surge in capital funding that ignores the practicalities of spending it or resourcing the increased running costs that result. In short, a strategic approach involving measured growth across all defence lines of development and integrated with allies is required,â€ he says.&nbspStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: crucial role junk dna revealed whole human genome finally decoded
story: The entire human genome has finally been sequenced, nearly 20 years after scientists first claimed to have made the breakthrough.In 2003, researchers from the Human Genome Project announced that the blueprint of life had been decoded but they had missed out around eight per cent of DNA, believing it was repetitive and unimportant.Since then experts have come to realise that this junk DNA plays a crucial role in human biology, and have finally sequenced the missing pieces - a development that may finally explain why some people develop certain traits and are at greater risk of disease.The size of the missing chunk is so large that scientists say it is the equivalent of deciphering a whole new chromosome.â€œFinishing the human genome sequence was like putting on a new pair of glasses,â€ said Dr Karen Miga, of the University of California, Santa Cruz.â€œNow that we can clearly see everything we are one step closer to understanding what it all means.â€The 19-year endeavour to complete the picture has involved scientists from all over the world, including Cambridge University and the Wellcome Sanger Institute.Much of the newly decoded material comes from the centre of chromosomes - or centromeres - and the very tips - the telomeres - both of which are linked to cell ision and the development of cancer and degenerative diseases.The team discovered more than 100 new genes that produce proteins, the molecules which do most of the work in cells and that are required for the structure, function, and regulation of tissues and organs.However, they also found mysterious pockets of non-coding DNA that do not make proteins but still seem to play an important role in cellular functions and may lie at the heart of conditions in which cell ision runs amok, such as cancer.â€œWe are finally digging into what we once called junk DNA, because we could not understand it or look at it accurately,â€ said Dr Giulio Formenti of the Rockefeller University, New York.â€œWe now know that many diseases are linked to structural repeats in the centromere, and now that these sequences are no longer missing from the human reference genome we can begin to map the origins of these diseases.â€To complete the genome, scientists used DNA from a non-cancerous tumour called a hydatidiform mole, which occurs when a human embryo rejects DNA from the mother and instead duplicates DNA from the father.This mistake in fertilisation means the tumour has DNA from just one inidual, making it easier to sequence. This, coupled with advances in genetic sequencing over the past two decades, allowed researchers to fill in the gaps.â€œYou would think that, with 92 per cent of the genome completed long ago another eight per cent wouldnâ€™t contribute much,â€ said Prof Erich Jarvis of Rockefeller.â€œBut from that missing eight per cent, weâ€™re now gaining an entirely new understanding of how cells ide, allowing us to study a number of diseases we had not been able to get at before.â€The breakthrough could also help unpick the origins of humanity. Some of the genes that were missing in the original genome are now thought to be critically important in driving the bigger, more connected brains which separate humans from apes.Researchers also found that the centromeres contained layers of older sequences which appear to be no longer used by the cell but may hold clues to how our DNA worked in the past.â€œIt's almost like layers of fossils,â€ said Dr Nicolas Altemose, of University of California, Berkeley.â€œAs you move away from the site of the active centromere you get more and more degraded, to the point where if you go out to the furthest shores of this sea of repetitive sequences you start to see the ancient centromere.â€He added: â€œBefore, we just had the blurriest picture of what was there, and now it's crystal clear.â€The research, by members of the Telomere-to-Telomere consortium, was published in six papers in the journal Science.More from NewsRussian tank convoy in Ukraine may no longer exist, says USUkraine-Russia latest news: Unclear if huge Russian convoy to Kyiv still exists, US saysRamadan 2022: Fasting, prayer and how Muslims celebrate the revelation of the KoranApril Fool&#39s Day 2022: how Chaucer, calendar confusion and Hilaria led to pranks and fake newsChaos as Boris Johnson drops pledge to ban conversion therapy â€“ then appears to row back a few hours laterMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: jonathan van tam having sleepless nights spring covid booster
story: Jonathan Van-Tam said he is having sleepless nights worrying about over-75s coming forward for their spring booster jabs on his final appearance as England's Deputy Chief Medical Officer.Prof Van-Tam, who became one of most familiar faces of the Covid pandemic, announced in January that he would be resigning.Speaking at the Royal Society of Medicine's Covid conference on Thursday, his last appearance in the role, he said he was optimistic that countries were better prepared to respond to future pandemicsBut he warned: I wouldn't want anybody to take away from our discussion â€¦ the idea that this is over, because case rates here in the UK are really, really high and hospitalisations in London, for example, are becoming exceptionally high again.And what keeps me awake at night is whether the people we have called, over-75s, for their second booster dose are going to come forward really rapidly in the next few days and weeks, because it's going to be important.His comments come after Sir Patrick Vallance, the government's Chief Scientific Adviser, said four-monthly boosters cannot continue and that it was likely the NHS would move to an annual jab programme.The latest official figures show 15,632 people in England were in hospital with Covid as of Wednesday, up 18 per cent week-on-week and the highest since Jan 19 when the number was 15,742.Average daily hospital admissions in England of people with Covid currently stand at 2,050 â€“ the highest since Feb 5, 2021. But the proportion of hospital patients with Covid in England who are being treated primarily for something else is broadly unchanged at just over half.Across the UK, 19,534 patients were in hospital with Covid as of March 30. The last time that was higher was Jan 17m, when the figure stood at 19,657.More from NewsRussian tank convoy in Ukraine may no longer exist, says USUkraine-Russia latest news: Unclear if huge Russian convoy to Kyiv still exists, US saysRamadan 2022: Fasting, prayer and how Muslims celebrate the revelation of the KoranApril Fool&#39s Day 2022: how Chaucer, calendar confusion and Hilaria led to pranks and fake newsChaos as Boris Johnson drops pledge to ban conversion therapy â€“ then appears to row back a few hours laterMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: point keir starmer
story: Whatever his faults, nobody can claim that Sir Keir Starmer had the easiest start as Labour leader. Heâ€™s had to deal with the reputational damage of Corbynism, then a pandemic during which peopleâ€™s faith in government skyrocketed, followed by the war in Ukraine which has boosted the domestic popularity of Western leaders. Such conditions donâ€™t really give the Opposition much to work with.But there are no excuses left now. The Government threw away its poll lead in the autumn with its bid to avoid Owen Paterson being suspended, then trampled over any residue support with the Partygate saga. Now the nation is sailing towards a severe cost-of-living crisis, with Rishi Sunak â€“ once the most popular politician in Britain â€“ on the ropes.Â This should be Starmerâ€™s moment to show us what heâ€™s made of, what he believes. And todayâ€™s launch of his local election campaign was a fantastic opportunity. Yet he still struggled to generate any sense of excitement about the prospect of Labour governance, whether local, regional or national.Â There are, to be fair, some inidually eye-catching policies. The pledge to reduce peopleâ€™s energy bills by up to Â£600 will get some voters to sit up and take notice. But even this is a clunky, short-term, tactical move funded by that perennial socialist favourite: a â€œwindfall taxâ€ on energy companies. If the Labour leader has a structural plan to deliver long-term energy security, it is being cruelly ignored by the media.Â In recent weeks we have seen every suggestion of ways to support energy security (fracking, small modular nuclear reactors, and onshore wind) run into difficulty, with powerful coalitions of Nimbys prepared to campaign against any change to infrastructure. How would Starmer unpick this Gordian knot? What would he build, and where? We donâ€™t know. Just saying â€œthis isnâ€™t good enoughâ€ isnâ€™t good enough. Britain deserves better than â€œBritain deserves betterâ€.This problem is not confined to energy policy. A similar gap between Labour's words and policies can be highlighted as soon as Starmer criticises the Tories on the economy, as he did today. â€œYou know the reality â€“ prices are going through the roof, and wages are going through the floor,â€ he said. â€œA Conservative government that takes far more than it gives to working people. The biggest drop in living standards since the 50s. Taxes the highest in 70 years.â€Does this mean that Labour wouldnâ€™t raise taxes? Starmer has apparently singled out the National Insurance rise. Thatâ€™s fair enough in isolation â€“ the Prime Ministerâ€™s vaunted â€œsocial care levyâ€ is unjust on younger people â€“ but how else will Labour manage to fund its vast ambitions for the NHS? There are only so many â€œwindfall taxesâ€ one can pull off.The fundamental problem with Labourâ€™s approach is that it is simply not possible to be on everyoneâ€™s side in a situation where different parts of the electorate have ergent, even opposed, interests. Until Starmer finds the courage and imagination to pick his side, he will never be able to carve out a better-defined and more realistic vision for the country.Â As times get tougher, pointing at the Tories and screaming â€œBad Party!â€ might be enough to win Labour some new councils and perhaps even carry them back into office. But if the Labour leader has learned anything from the Prime Minister over the past few years, it should be that winning office without a coherent plan for power is a recipe for drift and missed opportunities.More from NewsRussian tank convoy in Ukraine may no longer exist, says USPutin may be self-isolating from his military advisers, says White HouseRamadan 2022: Fasting, prayer and how Muslims celebrate the revelation of the KoranApril Fool&#39s Day 2022: how Chaucer, calendar confusion and Hilaria led to pranks and fake newsChaos as Boris Johnson drops pledge to ban conversion therapy â€“ then appears to row back a few hours laterMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: pupils covid should stay home three days not five says guidance
story: Pupils who test positive for Covid have been advised to stay at home for three days instead of five amid fears of missing time in the classroom.While adults have been advised to isolate for five days if they test positive, new guidance published by the Department for Education on Thursday said under-18s should isolate for three in order to balance the risk of transmission with continued disruption to education.A UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) spokesman told The  that while the risk of harm to children and young people from Covid is low, the harms of missed and disrupted education are significant.The advice covers how schools in England should approach living with Covid from April 1. It follows guidance from the Department of Health, which said that from Friday anyone with a positive test result will be advised but not legally required to try to stay at home and avoid contact with other people for five days.The UKHSA spokesman said: There is some evidence that children have a shorter duration of illness compared to adults, and this guidance balances the risk of transmission with continued disruption to education.It came as a plan to develop vaccines within 100 days of a completely new pandemic was on Thursday questioned by the lead scientist on the Oxford jab.Prof Dame Sarah Gilbert, who led the development of the AstraZeneca vaccine, said it was going to take a lot longer than 100 days to determine whether a jab would work against a new infection.Last year, Sir Patrick Vallance, the government's Chief Scientific Adviser, launched the 100 Days Mission in partnership with G7 countries, which aims to have vaccines, testing and drugs available quickly in the event of an outbreak.At a Royal Society event in London, Dame Sarah said it would be wonderful to have early access to treatments and jabs, but questioned whether the goal was achievable.What about the clinical development? she asked. What about knowing that the vaccine works? How are we going to achieve that, particularly when it's a novel pathogen and not one that we already know about? That's going to take a lot longer than 100 days.Sir Patrick said it was important to start on the road, adding: It's not going to be possible for lots of things for many, many, many, many years, but it provides a sort of an aiming point.Â More from NewsRussian tank convoy in Ukraine may no longer exist, says USUkraine-Russia latest news: Unclear if huge Russian convoy to Kyiv still exists, US saysRamadan 2022: Fasting, prayer and how Muslims celebrate the revelation of the KoranApril Fool&#39s Day 2022: how Chaucer, calendar confusion and Hilaria led to pranks and fake newsChaos as Boris Johnson drops pledge to ban conversion therapy â€“ then appears to row back a few hours laterMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: rishi sunak shows disregard consequences
story: Rishi Sunak shows disregard for consequences of poverty as Brits face bills crisisWater bills are going up, council taxes are rising and energy bills are set to increase by more than %. The Tories are either blind to the misery they are overseeing or completely indferent to itRishi Sunak could have helped Brits with last weeks Spring Statement Image: via REUTERSopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Apr |commentsHome across the land are this morning braced for a fresh wave of economic pain. Water bills are going up, council taxes are rising and energy bills are set to increase by more than %. The hike in National Insurance contributions will soon follow.All this against a backdrop of runaway inflation, stagnant wages and soaring food and fuel costs. Families already struggling face a grim future as the crisis really starts to bite.The Tories are either blind to the misery they are overseeing or completely indferent to it.Chancellor Rishi Sunak had a chance in last weekâ€™s spring statement to help us through this storm. The Government did not have to sit on the sidelines. It was not powerless to act.It could have raised pensions and benefits in line with inflation. It could have imposed a windfall tax on the oil and gas giants. It could have halted the National Insurance rise coming into force on April . The fact the Chancellor opted for the bare minimum shows not only how little he understands stricken families but also displays callous disregard for consequences of poverty. This is a crisis made in Downing Street. Hard-up Britain is paying the price.  Curb killers Three young people have been killed by out-of-control dogs in less than a month. These tragic deaths are even more upsetting because they were preventable. They happened because of a failure to control ownership of dangerous dogs. Laws could have been strengthened to stop the sale and breeding of aggressive breeds. There could have been tougher penalties for owners who fail to control their lethal animals. How many more deaths will it require before ministers act  No Snickering A quarter of young people would rather have a choc bar than sex. Apparently itâ€™s how they get their Twix these days. Many will think they must be from Mars. story: Weakened Vladimir Putin has already lost Ukraine war, says UK armed forces chiefAdmiral Sir Tony Radakin has also claimed the blueprint published last March identied Moscow as the biggest threat to the UKâ€™s securityThe Chief of the Defence Staff Admiral Sir Tony Radakin Image: WIktor Szymanowicz NurPhoto REX ShutterstockByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Britainaposs top military officer has said Vladimir Putin has already lost and is weaker than he was a month ago.Admiral Sir Tony Radakin has also claimed the blueprint published last March identied Moscow as the biggest threat to the UKâ€™s security.Five weeks after Vladimir Putinâ€™s forces waged war on their neighbour, he said: â€œI think we will have to look and explore and understand what the events in Ukraine mean and what impact does that have on the Integrated Review, and I think thatâ€™s perfectly fair.I think it would be insane not to have the humility or the curiosity to look again at what we can learn from whatâ€™s going on.The -page document, â€˜Global Britain in a competitive age: The Integrated Review of Security, Defence, Development and Foreign Policyâ€™, said: â€œNATO will remain the foundation of collective security in our home region of the Euro-Atlantic, where Russia remains the most acute threat to our security.â€It added that Russia â€œwill remain the most acute direct threat to the UKâ€.  However, critics have called for the review to be reopened and more money to be pumped into the armed forces following the outbreak of war in Europe. Defending the study, Adm Sir Tony told Whitehallâ€™s Institute for Government think-tank: â€œIt rightly identied Russia as an acute threat, it reinforced that the way that we best protect our national security against that particular threat is through collective defence - and we are in the worldâ€™s most powerful military alliance, called NATO.â€  The former First Sea Lord said British troops â€œmust be more active and engaged in the worldâ€ to â€œprotect and advance the national interest and our shared democratic valuesâ€. Rivals were trying to â€œchallenge and undermine the international, rules-based system here in Europe and whereâ€, warned the naval officer.  He also launched a blistering personal attack on the Russian President, whom he branded â€œa weaker and more diminished figure today than he was a month agoâ€. â€œIn many ways, Putin has already lost,â€ said Adm Sir Tony, . â€œFar from being the far-sighted manipulator of events that he would have us believe, Putin has damaged himself through a series of catastrophic misjudgements. â€œHe has failed to recognise how deeply the notions of sovereignty, democracy and national identity have taken root in Ukraine.  â€œLike all authoritarians, he allowed himself to be misled as to his own strength, including the effectiveness of the Russian armed forces. â€œHe has failed to anticipate the unity and cohesion that exists among the free nations of the world, here in Europe and obviously far beyond. â€œHis actions to date have done more to galvanise than ide and have shown Ukraine to have the one thing that Russia conspicuously lacks, which is real friends.â€ Adm Sir Tony described NATO as â€œstronger and more united than at any time I can rememberâ€. The only party he cares about is the Conservative Party, and his leadership of it. His sense of timing is immaculate. story: Exclusive: Boy expelled from school at age FOUR - and has been stuck at home for  monthsLaura Jordan said her son Zac is now scared to leave the house after spending five months at home following his expulsion from Holly Hill Church School, in Rubery, WorcestershireLaura Jordan said her son Zac has become withdrawn since being expelled from school Image: Mark RadfordByMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsA boy has been stuck at home for five months after being expelled from school at just four years old. Laura Jordan said her son Zac, now five, has spent so much time in the house that heaposs now scared to go outside. She was shocked to discover that councils are not required to get kids back into schoolthey are expelled before their fth birthday. The boy was booted out of Holly Hill Church School, in Rubery, Worcs, in October after a number of behaviour problems, including attacks on other pupils and staff.But his mum, , believes he has undiagnosed special educational needs that canapost be dealt with in mainstream schools.Worcestershire County Council has since apologised for failing to find a suitable school for Zac and said it is working with his mum to get him back into education. Laura, from Redditch, Worcs, told The Mirror: Zac started reception in September and within five weeks he had been permanently excluded.Ever since heaposs been out of school as he was only four and the compulsory school age is five. Itaposs very rare for this to happen to a child his age.Itaposs pure discrimination, the whole thing. I donapost think itaposs morally right heaposs out of school when people the same age as him are able to go to school. Heaposs been left behind because heaposs been excluded and offered no alternative schooling provision.Heaposs missed out on his education. This is going to affect him for the rest of his le.Laura said Zac has become increasingly isolated following his exclusion last October.  She added: I canapost even get him to leave the house. I have to force him to leave just to go to the shops. He used to be happy outside the house. Now he doesnapost want to leave and thataposs because heaposs not mixing with kids his age.The mum-of-two does not deny that her son has issues, accepting that he attacked other children and staff at his school. However, she believes he has autism, ADHD and speech and language problems which make certain situations aposoverwhelmingapos for him. Laura added: He was excluded because heaposs got special educational needs and the school was not able to meet his needs. They couldnapost keep him and others safe. But they couldaposve done other things before resorting to excluding him. This wouldaposve involved a possible managed move or alternative provision.  Ultimately, they didnapost give him chance or time to adjust to his environment or the new staff in his classroom.She added that Worcestershire County Council has to find Zac a new school by April after he turned five in February. The mum said: Itaposs down to the local authority to find an alternative school for him. They have requested two special needs schools but they said they are full. The council now want him in a local mainstream school. If the school accepts him, he will have no choice but to go there.I fear he will be excluded againhe is chucked into another mainstream school and we will be on this never ending cycle of him going to schools and getting excluded. Laura now thinks the UKaposs compulsory school age should be lowered to four-years-old so children cannot be expelled and left at home once they have started education. A Department for Education spokesperson said: â€œSuspensions and permanent exclusions should only be used as a last resort, but we back headteachers to suspend or exclude pupils where it is necessary and helps maintain calm classrooms. â€œWe are consulting on changes to behaviour and exclusions guidance to make sure this is used in a fair way, and the cross-government SEND Review will further consult on how children with special educational needs and disabilities are supported by the system, including in alternative provision.â€ Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Local authorities are responsible for arranging full-time education for excluded pupils once they reach compulsory school age.Worcestershire County Councilaposs cabinet member for education Marcus Hart said: â€œParent carers have a statutory right to ask for a particular educational setting and support for their child but it can at times be challenging to find the right place that has capacity and can meet a childâ€™s inidual needs. The law requires all children to start full-time education by the beginning of the term following their fth birthday and we are working with Ms Jordan to find a suitable and appropriate school that meets Zacâ€™s assessed needs, ready for him to start school in April. We are sorry that we have been unable to source an educational provision for Zac that has been able to meet his needs for this period and we acknowledge this is unacceptable for Zac, indeed for any child. We are continuing to work alongside Ms Jordan and relevant healthcare providers and partners to ensure that we have a high quality, lawful Educational Health and Care Plan in place for Zac, that will help to ensure he receives the tailored help and support he needs at all stages of his educational journey.â€ Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Children SchoolsSchools" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Covid could reset and dodge all vaccines with future pandemic certain, expert warnsSpeaking at a virtual Royal Society conference, the Governments chief scientic adviser for England also said the "world needs to be ready" for inevitable future pandemics which look very dferent to the current oneThe Governments chief scientic adviser for England also said the world needs to be ready for inevitable future pandemics Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A coronavirus iant which escapes vaccine immunity could take the world by surprise, Sir Patrick Vallance has warned.Speaking at a virtual Royal Society conference, the Governmentaposs chief scientic adviser for England also said the world needs to be ready for inevitable future pandemics which look very dferent to the current one.Sir Patrick told scientists at the meeting about the  Days Mission, an initiative which aims to prevent future pandemics before they start, according to the Government.The mission works towards a target of being able to develop effective vaccines, therapeutics and testing within  days of an epidemic or pandemic threat being identied. Sir Patrick told the Royal Society meeting: Itaposs very obvious to everyone in this meeting that there will be a future pandemic. That I think is clear.  Itaposs also clear this one is not over and weaposve got very high infection rates at the moment. And the room for this virus to evolve remains very large, so we could be taken by surprise again with a iant that escapes immunity. He added: Weaposve got no idea what the next pandemic might be and it certainly wonapost be the same as this one. Whatever it is, the world needs to be ready to respond. Sir Patrick also said he is pleased that a big uplt of Â£ billion in funding up to  for le sciences research, including work aiming to prevent future pandemics, was included in the Spending Review.  But he added that a decade of underfunding for Public Health Englandundermined the UKaposs response to the pandemic in . He said: Some things were underfunded, and that underfunding undermined the ability operationally to do things. The underfunding of Public Health England for virtually a decade beforehand was an important part of why certain things were dficult and itaposs very important that we donapost fall into that trap again.Sir Patrickaposs speech comes as free coronavirus testing comes to an end this week for most people, as part of the Governmentaposs Living with Covid plan.From Friday, most people will need to shop on the high street for paid-for teststhey want them. news uk-news day-day-le-uks-most-"Robert Maudsley says that he is capable of anythingByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsMass murderer Robert Maudsley, who is serving a le sentence for brutally killing four people, has warned heaposll kill againheaposs ever released. The monstrous killer, who is being held in Wakefield Prison, has already spent  years living in solitary confinement in a glass cage after he was deemed too dangerous to be around other prisoners. But although heaposs previously complained his interment reminded him of a traumatic childhood, it has been reported heaposs now quite content living in the underground box. Speaking in a new documentary aposHMP Wakefield: Evil Behind Barsapos Maudsleyaposs nephew Gavin said his uncle is perfectly happy.  He added his softly spoken, well-read uncle would kill againhe was ever released back into society. Maudsley, from Toxteth, Liverpool, was just  when he committed his first murder in .  For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here The serial killer, who had been working as a rent boy at the time, butchered one of his clients, John Farrell. The murder was so violent, cops named him blue because of the colour of his face. Maudsley was arrested and eventually convicted of murder. He was jailed with the recommendation he should never be released. When he was first locked up Maudsley was sent to Broadmoor Hospital, which houses some of the UKaposs most violent prisoners. After three relatively quiet years behind bars, the serial killer seized an opportunity to attack child molester David Francis in , with the help of fellow prisoner David Cheeseman. The pair barricaded themselves in a cell with Francis before spending the next nine hours brutally torturing the sex offender to death. During the attack, Maudsley shoved a spoon so far into Francisaposs ear, it wedged into his brain.  After the killing, for which he was convicted of manslaughter, he was deemed too dangerous to stay in Broadmoor and was transferred to Wakefield Prison. But Maudsleyaposs streak for vigilante violence continued and after heaposd settled into his new cell the following year, he strangled and stabbed we-killer Salney Darwood and hid the body under his bed. Thirsty for more blood, he hunted prison corridors for his next victim - Bill Roberts, who had been jailed for sexually abusing a seven-year-old girl. He stabbed Roberts to death before hacking at his skull with a makesht dagger. After the bloodshed, Maudsley calmly walked up to a prison guard and chillingly said there would be two fewer people at dinner that night. His rampage rung alarm bells for prison bosses who deemed him too dangerous to mix with the general prison population and a special cell was constructed to keep him in. The cell, which was completed in , was dubbed the glass cage - as it resembled Anthony Hopkinsapos cell in Silence of the Lambs. At .mx.m, itaposs surrounded by bulletproof glass which prison guards peer into to keep a close eye on him.  The only furniture is a table and a chair, which are both made of compressed cardboard, while his toilet and sink are bolted to the floor. The door of the cell is made of solid steel, which opens into a cage just inside. Maudsleyaposs bed is a concrete slab. The see-through walls contain a slit, through which guards pass him meals and other things he needs. Spending his days entombed in the cell, Maudsley is allowed one hour of exercise per day. When he goes to the exercise yard, heaposs escorted by six guards and he never has access to other inmates. When interviewed, Maudsley said he felt tortured in solitary confinement and claimed his speech has suffered from never speaking to anyone. He said: I feel no officer takes any interest in me and theyaposre only concerned with when to open the door and then to make sure I get back in my cell as soon as possible. I think an officer could stop and talk a bit but they never do and itaposs these thoughts that I think about most of the time. But in a letter to Gavin, , he claimed he is happy and content in the box and has warned killing will be on his mindheaposs ever released. Maudsley has claimed the confinement has given him flashbacks to his childhood, when he was regularly locked away and beaten. The serial killer had an abusive childhood at the hands of his father. After being dumped in an orphanage as an infant, his parents brought him and his  siblings home when he was eight. He was regularly hit and often took extra beatings to protect his siblings. Once, he was locked in a room for six months, with his only human contact coming from beatings from his dad. In the year  Maudsley asked for the terms of his imprisonment to be relaxed - begging for a pet budgie or,that request was denied, a cyanide capsule so he could end his le. Both requests were turned down, leaving him to live out his days in the glass cell underneath Wakefield Prison. title: ex head girl accused faking
story: Ex-head girl accused of faking old headmistress will in bid for her Â£.million estateLeigh Voysey, , claims the sprawling estate was left to her by Maureen Renny before she died because she feared her blood family would sell it to developersLeigh Voysey claims her former head teacher instructed her to write a new will, leaving a multi-million estate to her Image: Champion NewsByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar A former head girl has been accused of faking the will of her old headmistress in a bid to claim her Â£.million estate. Maureen Renny, the former head of the independent fee-paying Barn School, left her Â£.milion seven-bed detached house to her family. However, Leigh Voysey, , claims it was left to her to save it from developers. The sprawling Hill House in Much Hadham, Herts, was the site of The Barn School until . Ms Voysey started attending the school in , when she was eight. The mum-of-one claims Mrs Renny had always favoured her, giving her the best parts in class plays, and that she reconnected with her old mentor by chance during the last three years of her le.She claims the former head asked her to write out a will and organise a friend to sign it on Mrs Rennyaposs behalf in September  over fears it would be sold to developersleft to her blood family. Ms Voysey claims Mrs Renny knew she loved the old schoolhouse as much as she did and decided to leave her everything. Mrs Rennyaposs cousins and the children of her stepson had stood to inherit it from a  will.  Now Mrs Rennyaposs relatives are fighting Ms Voyseaposs bid to claim the fortune in Londonaposs High Court. They have accused the former head girl of faking the  will. Mrs Renny died, aged , in January , four months after the new will to leave her Â£.million estate to the former pupil was allegedly made, court documents say. The  will ide the estate between her cousins Gillian Ayre, Angela Eastwood and Susan Vickers, and the children of her stepson, Thomas and Katherine Renny. Ms Voysey claims she bonded with her former headteacher after visiting her as a carer and then a friend in . She claims she wrote her distant blood relatives out of her will because she feared they would sell the old schoolhouse to developers. She claims Mrs Renny asked her to write out the will and have it signed on her behalf because she could not do so herself due to problems with her eyesight.  In papers lodged with the court, she says: Mrs Renny remembered exactly who I was, even though it was  years since Iaposd left her school. Mrs Renny told me that sheaposd been asking about me during the years since I had left her school. The whole experience that day was very touching. I worked one more sht as a carer for Mrs Renny, then visited her as a friend after that. After reconnecting in February , I visited Mrs Renny when I could... approximately three to four times a year. When I visited Mrs Renny, I would make us both a cup of tea and we would talk about my time when I was at The Barn. We both enjoyed that immensely. During one of my visits, she asked me what I thought about The Barn, i.e. Hill House, and I said I loved it. Mrs Renny said to me aposI hope it never gets built onapos.  Ms Voysey said the former headteacher says she wanted to leave her estate to her in a new will. In September , Mrs Renny arranged for two of the former head girlsapos pals to witness a new will because she didnapost want her family to know she was doing a new one, it has been claimed. In the papers, Ms Voysey says: Mrs Renny asked me to complete the  will and dictated to me what she wanted to be written on it. Mrs Renny was unable to sign the will herself as she had problems with her eyesight. Kate Selway QC, representing Mrs Rennyaposs family, says in the defence to the action: It is the defendantsapos case that the  will was the deceasedaposs last true will. The  will is invalid because it was procured by the claimantaposs fraudulent conduct. It is denied that the claimant had any ongoing acquaintance with the deceased after leaving The Barn School. It is averred that the only other material time that the deceased and the claimant met was on th February  when the claimant was working as a carer... and worked a lunchtime sht looking after the deceased that day. The claimant cared for the deceased only once for a few hours over lunchtime on th February . The claimant undertook no more shts as a carer for the deceased and never visited the deceased again. It is denied that the deceased made the  will or any will leaving her estate to the claimant. The alleged events said by the claimant to have taken place...never happened. The deceased never signed the  will. The  will was completed in the claimantaposs handwriting and allegedly witnessed by two friends of the claimant who were not known to the deceased. The barrister says it was impossible for the blank will to have been on the table when Ms Voysey arrived, since Mrs Renny was so frail she could not get out of her chair or even hold a telephone. Ms Voysey claimed: I think it was more important to Mrs Renny that she left her estate to me to save The Barn Hill House and the surrounding land from development rather than leave her estate to her distant blood relatives. She further claimed the former head told her she had rejected a Â£m offer from developers for the land and house. Ms Selway is also raising an alternative defence to the claim, stating that Mrs Renny lacked the testamentary capacity to execute the will and did not know or approve of its contents, evenit wasnapost faked. story: Gov to get , people new jobs by June - find outyou fit the criteriaThe UK Governmentâ€™s Way to Work plan is getting job-ready candidates into new roles â€“ and supporting employers in finding the right staffWork Coaches at Jobcentre Plus are already helping thousands of employers connect with the people they needAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar Looking to find a new job or fill a vacancy  Through Way to Work, Jobcentre Plus is offering employers a recruitment service that can quickly provide candidates who are the perfect fit. Jobcentre Plus has everything you need to move quickly. Right now, there are . million jobs available in sectors such as warehousing, logistics and manufacturing â€“ so there are plenty of opportunities out there. For employers, Jobcentre Plus has thousands of quality candidates, ready to fill your vacancies quickly. The pandemic has been tough on everyone and highly skilled people have found themselves unemployed for the first time.Many may be considering a career change. These people can make a real dference to your business. And the UK Government is working with employers to get , job-ready candidates into work by the end of June.Many well-known companies already trust Jobcentre Plus with their recruitment needs â€“ and you can too. To find out more, visit gov.uk waytowork. The family-run firm, based in Wrexham, produces textiles including T-shirts and printed bags â€“ and theyâ€™ve been keen to attract younger people to roles. â€œOne of the issues we have is the perception of manufacturing as being something we used to do in the Victorian age but no longer,â€ says director Ben Bristow. â€œOf course thatâ€™s not the case â€“ but it made it hard to attract young people. Working with Jobcentre Plus gave us the ability to get more young people into the business and provide them with a good grounding in print and textiles.  â€œOur staff collaborated really well with the team at Jobcentre Plus, who gave excellent support and deserve high praise indeed.â€ HR manager Lee Dixon, , agrees: â€œThe people who work there have done a fantastic job. Itâ€™s not been easy through Covid and the fact theyâ€™ve managed to help people into work is great. â€œItâ€™s also massively helpful to us as an employer, given there are loads of jobs but not enough people to fill them. Weâ€™ve also had people with additional learning needs and disabilities.â€apos My team made me feel very welcome and supported me apos â€œWhen I left college in January  I didnâ€™t finish my A levels because I wanted a change, but then obviously the pandemic happened. I didnâ€™t particularly know what I wanted to do, but I knew I would be good in a computer-based job because itâ€™s something that Iâ€™ve gravitated towards. â€œThen I saw JD Sports was advertising opportunities and I thought Iâ€™d go for it because it was an administration role in a big company. It was actually the first that I applied for and everything went through really quickly â€“ and I got the job. â€œMy team at JD were great from day one. They made me feel very welcome and supported me. Day to day Iâ€™d look after anything from HR queries and issuing contracts to payroll and pension questions. It gave me pretty much a whole picture of what itâ€™s like to work in HR and Iâ€™ve been doing it ever since. â€œIâ€™d always had an interest in HR, but after working for six months I realised it was what I wanted to do. â€œThere was the option to stay on and Iâ€™m now doing an apprenticeship with JD and CIPD Level  in HR support. It was another perfect step for me and Iâ€™ve now been there for a year and Iâ€™m really enjoying it. Starting work was quite tough, but Iâ€™ve got so much support from my team. Itâ€™s a lot more friendly than I expected it to be.â€œNow Iâ€™m learning about dferent parts of HR, building on what I was doing before. I was struggling to find any job with noexperience, but now Iâ€™ll just keep going.â€Peter Cowgill, executive chairman of JD Sports, on how the company has forged links with Jobcentre Plus. â€œWe are proud to have worked with Jobcentre Plus to provide much-needed employment and learning and development opportunities at a time when competition for job positions has been at an all-time high. Social inequality has only been exacerbated during the pandemic, so it has never been more vital to give young people a chance to succeed. â€œOur relationship with the DWP now covers all three nations across the UK and gives our stores, head office and distribution centres access to new talent pipelines and initiatives, which not only facilitates our future recruitment needs, but also allows us to support candidates facing social barriers, an area we are hugely passionate about.â€ â€œWhen I was developing my start-up in the renewable energy sector, working with Jobcentre Plus allowed me to recruit new graduates. â€œWeâ€™re part of the Edinburgh Business School incubator, where we get office space, mentoring and support. Since the graduates joined, weâ€™ve moved to the stage of building a prototype.â€œIf it wasnâ€™t for the scheme, recruitment would have been years away â€“and having a few more minds to work on the concept has given us a competitive edge.â€œThe candidates knew when they joined that they wouldnâ€™t just be working on their own tasks and would be learning something every single day. If youâ€™re looking for experience, itâ€™s a great way to get it.â€apos Itâ€™s important to personalise our service apos â€œOur service helps employers and our customers meet each other face to face, which is crucial. Employer advisers speak to both employers and the Work Coaches, whoâ€™ll send customers over who are ready for work. â€œWe can also help employers st through CVs and hold training events to get people work-ready and match them up with the role theyâ€™ve got available. â€œIâ€™ve been working closely with Lee at Paul Bristow Associates, who came along to events at the jobcentre where groups of young people could come and speak to him about what roles they had available. â€œA lot of employers werenâ€™t aware of all the great services we offer, but the feedback weâ€™ve been getting has all been really positive. title: man cycled around city randomly
story: Man cycled around city randomly stabbing women after being stood up by dateDermott McIlveen randomly stabbed six women in Belfast as he cycled past them in what a judge called a "violent rampage" following a date where he was stood up and felt humiliatedDermott McIlveen stabbed six women in a violent rampage Image: Police handoutByAshleigh McdonaldTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments A man who went on a violent rampage cycling around Belfast and randomly stabbing women after being stood up by a date, has been jailed. Dermott McIlveen attacked six women in October  during a two hour period due to feeling humiliated and that women were responsible for the problems he had in his le, reported BelfastLive. The defendant appeared via a videolink from Maghaberry prison at Belfast Crown Court where it emerged he was arrested after family members who saw a police appeal about the attacks got in contact. McIlveen, , admitted a total of seven offences committed on October , , with the charges include wounding, attempted wounding and possession of a kne with intent to commit wounding. As he imposed a sentence of nine years in custody followed by a period of three years extended licence, Judge Patrick Kinney QC spoke of the impact the attacks have had on all six victims.  He said: There is a need to protect women from violence by men such as the defendant. McIlveen, who was diagnosed with autism as a child, cycled round the streets of Belfast City Centre on a pushbike attacking women over a two-hour period. The first victim noticed a man on a bike in the Cathedral Quarter, and after walking to McDonaldaposs, she saw the same cyclist. She noticed he had a metal object in his hand, he bumped into her and short time later she noticed blood running down her leg and a cut to her right buttock. The second woman was walking home from work and was attacked at a set of traffic lights on Ormeau Avenue. After McIlveen approached her and stared at her, he jabbed her in her left arm before cycling off. A third victim was with a friend in Donegall Square West. A bicycle came behind her, and as she stepped over to let him past he stabbed her in the neck.  Another woman was in Bedford Street around .pm when a male on a bike hit her on the back of the head. Then McIlveenaposs next attack was on a woman as she walked along Dunluce Avenue, and on this occasion he punched his victim in the throat. The final assault occurred around pm on University Street, when McIlveen brushed up against a woman as he cycled past her and stabbed her in the hip. Crown barrister David Russell said that following the attacks, police launched an extensive investigation. CCTV images of the attacker were released in a media campaign, and after recognising McIlveen two relatives contacted police. McIlveen was arrested and claimed that whilst his memory of the attacks was not clear, he told police he had been on a date with a female on the day of October .  He said that after the woman got up and left him sitting on his own in a bar he felt humiliated - and this led to a decision to go and hurt woman as he felt females were responsible for everything that had gone wrong in his le. McIlveen admitted he wanted to slash one of the women in the face, and said he attacked another woman as she made him particularly angry after stepping onto the road as he cycled past. Judge Kinney said: It is an utterly repugnant idea that this perceived rejection could in some way justy his actions in attacking vulnerable females in public places.The defendant engaged in a determined and pre-meditated campaign to cause harm to innocent and vulnerable female victims. He deliberately chose to target young women and his violence had only one objective, and that was to hurt women.The judge said that after reading victim impact statements, the common theme is the distress by those McIlveen subjected to such random and serious violence.Defence barrister Patrick Lyttle QC said it was quite clear his client will need assistance whilst in prison for a range of psychological issues. Judge Kinney said that while he accepted there were medical issues, he agreed with a probation board assessment that McIlveen posed a serious risk of harm to the public and was a dangerous offender. Due to this assessment, Judge Kinney imposed an extended custodial sentence consisting of nine years custody followed by an extended licence period of three years in a bid to protect the public. The sentence means McIlveen may not be automatically released on licence after serving half his prison term. His release will be determined by parole commissioners, and when this occurs he will be on licence for a further three years.
