title: man ran life before dying
story: Man ran for his le before dying in citizens arrest headlock gone wrongChristopher Walters had been spotted running away from New Road Garage, in Longton where an Audi Aâ€™s windows had been smashed with a -pound sledgehammerHorried witnesses called  when they saw Christopher Walters, , being held in a â€˜tightâ€™ headlock Image: stokesentinelByKathie McInnes:,  Mar |comments A man died after aposrunning for his leapos and being placed under a citizensapos arrest, an inquest heard.Horried witnesses called  when they saw a -year-old male being held in a â€˜tightâ€™ headlock as two men tried to perform a citizensâ€™ arrest on him. Minutes earlier, Christopher Walters had been spotted running in Longton where an Audi Aâ€™s windows had been smashed with a -pound sledgehammer. Garage boss Jonathan Hassall and mechanic Benjamin Hunt gave chase, following him down a path near Gladstone Primary Academy.An inquest heard today how they tried to restrain him. But what began as a citizensâ€™ arrest turned into tragedy, reports StokeonTrent Live. Mr Walters was lying on the grass verge as Mr Hunt had him in a neck hold. The incident lasted for some minutes and he went into cardiac arrest.He was later pronounced dead at Royal Stoke University Hospital.Following his death, the Independent Office for Police Conductlooked into the time between the first police officer arriving on scene and CPR being started on Mr Walters.  It was established this gap had been one minute and  seconds â€“ a time described by North Staffordshire assistant coroner Sarah Murphy as â€˜reasonableâ€™ considering police didnâ€™t have the full facts when they arrived. The events unfolded shortly after lunchtime on May , . The Audi A belonged to the garage and was parked outside when the alarm went off. It was found with several windows smashed. A PE lesson was taking place in the nearby school grounds when Mr Walters was seen running down the path, out of breath and apparently â€˜huggingâ€™ the sledgehammer, with the others in pursuit. One witness, Ricky Amos, was driving past when he spotted Mr Walters lying down on the ground. â€œThe others were on top of him,â€ he recalled in a statement. Mr Hunt had his arms around Mr Waltersâ€™ neck. â€œHe had a tight grip of the manâ€™s neck. The man was struggling to worm himself out.â€ Mr Amos said he saw one of the males holding the sledgehammer in the air before hitting Mr Waltersâ€™ legs with it. Another passing driver, Michelle Leese, said in a statement: â€œI remember just seeing arms everywhere.â€ She also recalled seeing one of the men pick up the sledgehammer. At that point, she told her daughter, who was also in the car, to call the police. But the use of the hammer was later disputed by Mr Hunt. The -year-old, from Longton, is currently serving a -month sentence in prison after pleading guilty to manslaughter last year.  In his basis of plea, he said he deployed a headlock, but claimed neither he nor Mr Hassall had used weapons. Mr Hassall, , sadly took his own le days before he was due to stand trial. Forensic pathologist Dr Alexander Kolar, who carried out the post-mortem, noted injuries to the legs, but no evidence of blunt force trauma. He put the cause of death down to compression of the neck. Tests also showed Mr Walters, of Winchester Avenue, Bentilee, had used cannabis at some point before his death. The initial call to the police related to the vehicle damage. It was only while en route from Stone that an officer got an update about the suspect being restrained by members of the public. Sergeant Anthony McKenzie decided to go and assist in a police riot van. It turned out he was the first officer on scene. He saw Mr Walters being held by Mr Hunt, but said the â€˜grip did not appear to be firmâ€™. He told him to release the man. Sgt McKenzie began checking Mr Walters for a pulse. It was at this point that PCSO Toni Foyle was driving past and stopped to help. She said: â€œSgt McKenzie shouted to the male, â€˜Are you alright, mateâ€™. As he did this, the maleâ€™s face moved slightly. I saw his lips were blue and he had grass in his mouth. â€œI knelt down, putting him in the recovery position. I said, â€˜This man needs an ambulance urgentlyâ€™. I started chest compressions.â€ Addressing the inquest, Nicola Brooks, the solicitor for Mr Waltersâ€™ mother, said there was no evidence heâ€™d shown any aggression towards the men. She added: â€œHe was simply running away. As it turned out, he was running for his le and was cornered in an area of Wood Street, where he was set upon for some  to  minutes.â€ Concluding the death was due to unlawful killing, Ms Murphy said, on the balance of probabilities, Mr Walters had caused the vehicle damage. But she added: â€œHe didnâ€™t deserve to lose his le.â€ Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON University HospitalHospitals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Man squatting in Victorian-era grand hotel for six weeks - and hes been cleaning itTom, , has been squatting in Bristols -year-old Grosvenor Hotel and doing it up room-by-room for the past six weeks after leaving rehab and being unable to find official housing or supportTom, , moved into the dilapidated Grosvenor Hotel in Bristol around six weeks ago - and has been doing it up ever since Image: Martin Booth   SWNSByNeil ShawRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Britainaposs luckiest squatter now calls one of the UKaposs finest Victorian-era hotels his home. Tom, , started squatting in the -year-old abandoned Grosvenor Hotel in Bristol city centre around six weeks ago after being unable to find official housing when he left rehab.He gained entry to the building when he pushed on a key card door - and it opened. The hotel - which was originally built in  - has laid untouched and unused for around two decades, with rotting furniture now piling up in the rooms and graffiti daubed across its walls. Since moving in, Tom says heaposs been tidying up the rooms - even giving some of them a new lick of paint - to make them pleasant to live in once more.Every night he climbs the grand staircase and chooses a dferent bed to sleep in, so he is slowly renovating the hotel room-by-room, Wales Online reports. He enjoys stunning views across Bristol - although he does have to dodge precarious floors and beware of non-existent ceilings. Tom has created a living room with a sofa, a table and a few chairs and has cleared some of the junk off the floor - and is even painting a few of the walls. He said: â€œYou can tell this place used to be the real crÃ¨me de la crÃ¨me.aposaposSome of the wood, the dark mahogany wood, the wallpaper, the ornateness around the high ceilings, the detailed work. aposThere is so much heritage here. The people who have come through this place are amazing.â€ â€œThis is a wonderful building, thereâ€™s loads to it that I really enjoy. And to have a safe space inside.aposapos Tom says he thinks the hotel could be used to home Ukrainians here saying aposaposmaybe this hotel could be an answer to some short-term problemsaposapos. He grew up in Hertfordshire and has lived in Bristol for six weeks - struggling to find any official support after leaving rehab. Tom said: â€œI had found a key card down an alleyway and it just happened that when I used it on the swipe, the door opened. But the door was already open. aposI thought it was to do with the key card but it really wasnâ€™t. Iâ€™m gradually, slowly tidying up each room one at a time.  The building is caught in a planning row and Tom could be the last ever resident of the Grosvenor Hotel. The long running saga of the aposaposeyesoreaposapos near Temple Meads rail station reached its latest chapter this week. A report updating Bristol City Council plans to use a Compulsory Purchase Orderto acquire the former hotel in order to redevelop the land on which it is located. A â€˜decision pathwayâ€™ submitted to cabinet includes plans for a Joint Development  Land Agreementfor the development of the Temple Square siteand the purchase of Station Approach, as well as the proposed acquisition of land at Temple Square including the former Grosvenor Hotel.  The proposed CPO of the Grosvenor is part of a scheme expected to cost between Â£.m and Â£.m promised to deliver â€œsignicant city benefitsâ€¦ as an outcome of the long term economic growth driven by the George and Railway project alongside the wider regeneration achieved through a joint development and land agreementâ€., A decision on the future of the land and the buildings sitting on it â€“ once bisected by a famous flyover â€“ will be taken by Bristolâ€™s cabinet. Bristol City Council senior development surveyor, Jan Reichel, said in her report: â€œThe development will have the potential to achieve high sustainability outcomes, based on design proposals and the excellent accessibility of the developments at the heart of the Temple Quarter and near to Temple Meads Station.â€  Tom though says the Grosvenor Hotel is not just a name on a report or a building to be acquired - it is his home. He said: aposaposI often think about the transition between the people on the outside of the building going about their day to day, trying to race for something. aposaposIâ€™m sat here with infinite time, trying to collect myself in my own bits of meditation, but at the same time feeling like I can keep myself busy as thereâ€™s a lot to doâ€. story: Man tells of living with rats the size of dogs in mouldy council flatNic, , moved into his Hackney flat in  and claims that ever since he has had to cope with a horric pest infestation including huge rats the "size of his springer spaniel"Nic claimed there are rats the size of his dog in his flatBySylvie WilkinsonTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments A man has told about the horric pest infestation at his mouldy council flat, including rats the size of his springer spaniel dog, where he has been living for  yearsNic, , moved into his Hackney flat in  and he said that the problems of hygiene with insects and rodents as well as alleged antisocial behaviour from neighbours has been there ever since.He also claimed that the conditions at his home have added to his mental health illness that includes depression and social anxiety - which means he now feels uncomfortable going out on his own, reported MyLondon.â€œThere are rats that are the same size as my dog - Iaposve got a springer spaniel, said Nic. The mould has been treated numerous times but itâ€™s continuously growing back. They sent in one guy to paint the wall, but that didnâ€™t do anything to help.  Hackney Council responded saying since the last treatment of mould, theyaposve received no further reports.â€œItâ€™s terrible - I used to be a photographer, and I was outgoing and I could approach people and ask to take photos of them. Now, I donâ€™t talk to people, Nic continued. I donâ€™t go out. And because of the banging and hammeringand smashing about, I donâ€™t sleep.â€ Nic said there is a ratsâ€™ nest next to his property, and that the light fittings in his flatare filled with insects.At the same time he claims to have received persistent threats and abuse from his neighbours, and that some of them often play music at full volume throughout the night. He also says his neighbours have at times urinated outside his front door. Nicâ€™s best friend and carer Tora Peacock, , has been helping him in his fight to be moved somewhere more suitable. and because of Nicâ€™s mental health considerations, she has been contacting Hackney Council to have her friend moved, but to no avail.  â€œThe property isnâ€™t suitable for Nic. Ideally we just want him moved somewhere more suitable for his back and knee issues. Getting him moved is the main priority, but for the most partis not even answering the phone anymore, alleged Tora.She claims that, when trying to reach out to Hackney Council, the response has often been hostile saying she has even been â€œscreamed atâ€ by staff at the councilover the phone on a number of occasions - and has been told â€œnot to complainâ€.Together, Tora and Nic said they have made over  complaints about his living situation, though Tora has sent over  emails herself asking the council to act. Nic said he has requested to move homes around  times - he claims he was promised to be moved in , then again in , but is still stuck in the same place. Hackney Councilâ€™s Strategic Housing Director, Steve Waddington, told MyLondon: â€œThis is an extremely complex situation which we have been working closely for a number of years with [Nic] and his advocate Ms Peacock to resolve. We recognise that there are some aspects of [Nicaposs] complaint that we could have handled better, and we have and are continuing to take steps to remedy this. â€œFollowing reports of mould, we carried out a survey of [Nicaposs] home last year and found the issue was being exacerbated by lack of ventilation in the property. We took steps to treat the issue - including installing new fans in the kitchen and bathroom - and have had no further reports of mould since then. We are investigatingany other longer term steps are needed to tackle the issue and have also provided some advice to [Nic] on ways he can also help prevent it occurring. â€œWe have investigated reports made by [Nic] of noise nuisance, including visiting the property and providing noise monitors on several occasions, but so far have been unable to substantiate any evidence of this. However, we will continue to work with [Nic] about his concerns. We have and will continue to work with him around all housing options open to him.â€ The Mirror has contacted Hackney Council for comment. title: mum 28 gran 51 lifesaving
story: Exclusive: Mum, , and gran, , get lesaving heart transplants weeks after babys birthNatalie Bailey and her mum Jane both received heart transplants within weeks of little Maggie Lawrys birth. Jane was given a new heart in October  after  months on the transplant waiting listNatalie Bailey with her daughter Maggie and mum Jane Image: Daily Mirror Andy StenningByWarren MangerFeatures Writer:,  Mar |comments Little Maggie Lawry spent her first birthday surrounded by wrapping paper and presents... but the best gt of all was the presence of her mum and grandma. Mother and daughter Jane and Natalie Bailey had both suffered from failing hearts and each had received le-saving transplants within weeks of Maggieâ€™s birth from strangers she will never meet.Their case is so remarkable that surgeons at the countryâ€™s largest transplant centre, in Birmingham, have never seen anything like it before. Natalie, , says: â€œWe are so lucky to have both been given a second chance. Le could have been so dferent for Maggieit wasnâ€™t for our donors. â€œAndit wasnâ€™t for Maggie, I could have just dropped dead one day from heart failure.â€  Jane was given a new heart in October  after  months on the transplant waiting list. But the relief was short-lived as a few weeks later, Natalie discovered her heart was failing too. Worse still, Natalie was  weeks pregnant and the shock sent her into premature labour. She was rushed into surgery and Maggie was delivered by emergency Caesarean as doctors feared that neither would survive a natural birth. Natalie then needed a mechanical pump to send blood circulating around her body until a new heart could be found, as her own could no longer keep her alive. She was so ill she had a stroke and was put at the top of the â€œsupra-urgentâ€ list, so every donor heart was immediately checked to seeit was her match. Jane, , says: â€œI was still in hospital recovering when I found out Natalie needed a transplant too and the nurses took me to intensive care to see her. â€œIt was the first time Iâ€™d seen her for weeks, because coronavirus meant she couldnâ€™t visit me.â€œIt was scary seeing her on the heart pump, knowing that was the only thing keeping her alive. I blamed myself, because we had the same heart condition. It must be genetic. â€œThe only comfort was knowing I could answer any questions she had and support her, as Iâ€™d just been through the same thing. I knew the doctors were amazing and she was strong, so I clung to the hope she would recover and be the same person as before.â€ Natalie and Jane both suffered from a rare condition, dilated cardiomyopathy, which makes the walls of the main heart chamber too thin to pump blood. Jane developed breathing dficulties in mid- and scans showed her heart failing. She was fitted with a pacemaker that September and a donor heart was found just over a year later. She spent her th birthday in the Queen Elizabeth Hospital Birmingham after a transplant. When Natalie began suffering similar breathing dficulties, it was initially put down to low iron during her pregnancy. But when she was admitted to the same hospital with chest pains and her baby stopped moving, doctors found she too was suffering heart failure.Mum-of-four Natalie, from Birmingham, says: â€œIt was terrying, all this came out of nowhere. They were giving me oxygen and I still couldnâ€™t breathe. â€œThe doctor looked at me and said, â€˜I think we need to get that baby out of youâ€™. Then the contractions started and they took me straight to theatre becauseIâ€™d given birth naturally, neither of us would have made it.â€ Natalie didnâ€™t even get to hold Maggie before the baby was whisked away to the neonatal unit, where she spent the next two weeks with her dad Carl camped beside her cot. Natalieâ€™s condition got worse and two days later she was fitted with a mechanical heart. She says: â€œI was so ill some days Iâ€™d wake up and forget Iâ€™d had a baby.â€ Within a week a donor heart was found and Natalie had transplant surgery lasting more than  hours, but on the way back to the ward, she had a stroke.  When she woke, she could not speak or use her left arm or leg. But two days later, Natalie was able to see Maggie and hold her for the first time. She says: â€œCarl laid her in my lap and I was able to hold her bottle in my right hand to feed her. The emotion was overwhelming. â€œThe nurses said that they saw my recovery speed up after that, because I had a reason to get better.â€ Natalie spent eight weeks in hospital before ing home on December . Jane says: â€œWhen she came home, I hugged her and didnâ€™t want to let go. It felt amazing. Weâ€™d both made it through something terrible, but we were home in time to spend Christmas together.â€ Jane says: â€œIâ€™m so grateful to my donor, their family, and to Natalieâ€™s. My grandchildren got to keep their mum and their grandmother thanks to the courage and kindness of complete strangers.â€ Natalie and Jane have been recovering well after their transplants at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital, and will be forever grateful to the transplant team. Jorge Mascaro, director of heart and lung transplants, says: â€œThere was a lot of emotional pressure for the team. They had never treated two members of the same family at the same time before.â€ The hospital is trying to raise Â£million to create a national centre of excellence and increase transplants by %. As Natalie helped Maggie blow out the candles on her birthday cake, she made a special wish. She says: â€œI hope one day I can thank my donorâ€™s family and that seeing what a happy, loving family we are gives them some comfort.â€See organdonation.nhs.uk and support the fundraising for the new Birmingham Transplant Centre at hospitalcharity.org birminghamtransplantcentreRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BabiesHospitalsPregnancyGiving birthHeart diseaseImmune systemOrgan donationHeart transplantsCoronavirusDaily Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: newlyweds who spent wedding night
story: Newlyweds who spent wedding night in jail after brawl with mum now live separatelyClaire Goodbrand pleaded guilty to assault after the wedding night fight in June , which also involved her new husband, Eamonn Goodbrand, and Goodmans brother, who was best manClaire, Eamonn and Kieran Goodbrand all spent the night in jail following the weddingByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA bride who spent her wedding night in jail after she attacked her mum with a stiletto is now living apart from her new husband, it has been reported.Claire Goodbrand, , pleaded guilty to assault after the wedding night fight in June , which also involved her new husband, Eamonn Goodbrand, and Goodmanaposs brother, who was best man. It has now been reported that, despite marrying and Claire taking her husbandaposs name, the couple are now living separately from each other in dferent homes in Glasgow, although it is understood they still see each other, according to Mail Online. The disastrous end to their wedding three years ago happened after hours of heavy drinking, leading to a fight breaking out, the Mirror reported yesterday.Claire, a mother to four children, grabbed her own mum, Cherry-Ann Lindsay, , by the hair before hitting her with a stiletto. She also put her hands around her mumaposs throat.  Ms Lindsay told the Mail: She then grabbed me and put me in a choke hold. I couldnâ€™t breathe. I thought I was going to die. Neighbours told how the married couple are living apart in the Scottish city. A neighbour said: They donâ€™t live together no. Theyâ€™re at separate addresses a few miles apart and have been for a while. But they do still visit each other so itâ€™s not clear what the state of the relationship is. Claire attacked her mum and her mumaposs partner -year-old David Boyd, at which time Eamonn, a former professional boxer, and his brother Kieran joined in. David was punched, kicked, bitten and grabbed at the neck by the two brothers. They also pushed their thumbs into his eyes.  Kieran Goodbrand also punched and kicked Garry Brown, another guest at the wedding. Wedding day photos show the newly married couple beaming with happiness on the dance floor and standing for photos by water. Police were called to wedding venue The Vu at Ballencrieff Toll, Bathgate, in West Lothian after the fight, which spilled onto the lawn, was reportedly caught on CCTV. The bride, groom and best man were all arrested and held in custody that night. The couple plus their best man, who are all from Uddingston in Lanarkshire, pleaded guilty to assault and injury charges at Livingston Sherf Court this week. Claire Goodbrand pleaded guilty on indictment to assault to injury but not guilty to a more serious assault to severe injury.  She admitted repeatedly seizing her mother by the hair, punching and kicking her on the head and body, causing her to fall to the ground, before striking her head at The Vue wedding venue at Ballencrieff Toll in West Lothianâ€™s Bathgate Hills. She also admitted punching and kicking her mum Cherry-Ann to the head and body whilst she was on the ground, striking her on the head with a shoe and seizing her by the neck and restricting her breathing. Eamonn and Kieran both pled guilty to repeatedly punching and kicking David Boyd on the head and body while acting together. The charge states that they caused him to fall to the ground and continued their violent attack as he lay there. They admitted pushing their thumbs into Mr Boydâ€™s eyes, biting him on the head and body and repeatedly seizing him by the neck and restricting his breathing, all to his severe injury.In addition, Kieran Goodbrand admitted assaulting Garry Brown by punching and kicking him on the head and body to his injury at the reception on  June . A fourth member of the family, -year-old Brendan Goodbrand, had his not guilty pleas to two assault charges accepted by the Crown after his alibi that he had left the venue before trouble broke out turned out to be true. Sherf Martin Edington called for criminal justice social work reports on all three accused before passing sentence. He adjourned the case until  April for information on possible disposals, including social work supervision, unpaid hours of work and restriction of liberty by electronic curfew.Eamonn Goodbrandâ€™s Facebook page reveals that he works as a professional fighter, boxing competitively as a light middleweight.It was reported after the wedding reception that one of the alleged victims lost part of a finger during the attack. The prosecution will narrate the full circumstances when the case calls for sentence. Ms Lindsay said, to her, the wedding day felt like a sick joke. She said her daughter was swearing like a banshee and the boys were drinking beer and falling over each other. She said she began to sense trouble brewing but didnapost expect it to escalate so much. The -year-old said she has moved away to an undisclosed address and does not want to see them anymore. title: owner reunited dog stuck underground
story: Owner reunited with dog stuck underground after camping in the woods for  daysOwner Victoria Hogan feared her dog had been killed after disappearing into a badgers sett for  hours - but not wanting to give up on hope, she camped outdoors praying for her to make a Owner Victoria Hogan with Freda at the vets Image: Triangle NewsByAndy CrickPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsA terried dog spent  days stuck underground after disappearing down a badgeraposs sett. Owner Victoria Hogan was out walking her two border terriers when Freda darted down the hole.Her other dog, Bert, tried to follow her but was attacked by a badger.Victoria feared Freda had been killed, but camped out in the woods in the vague hope she would finally emerge.She was told to do anything for  hours by the Park Ranger and RSPCA as its illegal to disturb a badger den. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. The -year-old then cooked bacon and blew the aroma down into the hole with a leaf blower to try and coax her out. She also played recordings of Bert and other terriers howling thinking she might appear. Freda poked her head out a couple of times but then vanished again. However, she finally darted out of the sett in Lickey Hills Country Park, near Birmingham - after  hours - on Monday. Victoria Hogan, who lives with her vet husband Brian, , in Lickey, said: â€œI knew she was in there somewhere. â€œBut these setts can be extensive with several ways in and out, but I stayed there hoping sheâ€™d turn up.  â€œI was devastated and was believing she had been killed. I didnâ€™t say but Iâ€™d hoped sheâ€™d died quickly and not suffered in a tunnel deep below the ground. â€œBut I cooked bacon and blew the aroma down there with a leaf blower and even played recordings of Bert and other terriers howling thinking she might appear.â€ Freda was treated by vets for bite marks, deep pressure sores and dehydration. Victoria added: â€Iâ€™ll be keeping a close eye on Freda and Bert in the future. I just couldnâ€™t go through that again.â€ It comes just days after a border terrier spent six days inside a badger sett in Rowde, Wilts, after falling into it during a walk. Owner Annie Davidson put out a missing dog appeal fearing her dog - named Bumble - might have climbed out when she was not there. But then suddenly Bumble popped her head up like whack-a-mole and she clambered to safety. Annie said: Weaposre so delighted to have Bumble back home. The experience was traumatic for her. Bumble popped up and out of the badger sett. Very thin and dehydrated but fine otherwise. Elsewhere, a dog had to be rescued after getting stuck down a ft deep crevice on a mountain.Reggie, an -month-old spaniel, has been branded a little warrior after he survived the fall at Llwynypia Mountain in the Clydach forest in Wales.After being stuck for  hours, he was rescued and safely ed to his owners, who have said he is in good spirits despite his ordeal. story: Passenger stuck at airport for nearly four hours says travellers treated like cattleBecause of a litany of snags and glitches with aircraft handling, immigration and baggage delays, Ian Longley claims it wasnâ€™t until after pm he finally left the airportIan Longley was stuck at Manchester International Airport Image: Getty ImagesByCharlotte CoxGraeme Murray:,  Mar |commentsA passenger was stuck at an airport for almost four hours after y queues and staff shortages. Ian Longley had travelled from the sunshine hotspot of Verona, Italy but was hit by horrendous queues when he landed back at Manchester Airportapossapos terminal two. He claims he was was trapped there for almost four hours Staff shortages and queues were the main reason for his delays after landing with on March  at .pm. But because of a litany of snags and glitches with aircraft handling, immigration and baggage Ian claims it wasnâ€™t until after pm he finally left the airport Ian, , says he understands the unprecedented pressure that Manchester Airport is facing due to a range of issues, including staff shortages, sparked by the pandemic. But his biggest complaint is the way in which management dealt with his grumbles. He told Manchester Evening News: â€œI understand there are practical problems with things like Covid and recruitment but there were no staff. Not another single person in the building you could speak to.â€œThe one engineer we saw eventually swore at an elderly lady. â€œItâ€™s like passengers are an inconvenience, we are treated with contempt. Thereâ€™s a lack of information, a lack of people to speak to. We are treated like cattle. Iâ€™ve had enough of it. â€œWhat Iâ€™m trying to communicate with the airport is that itâ€™s not just about the queue, or that we were delayed. Thatâ€™s bad enough. Itâ€™s about how they treat people.â€ Manchester Airport, meanwhile, say the issues in question are managed by the Home Office and a handling agent, while they have endeavoured to deal with Ianaposs complaint in good time.  After arrival at the terminal, they were stuck on the aircraft for aposalmost an hourapos while staff waited for â€˜chocksâ€™ to secure the wheels. Manchester Airport has said the airlineâ€™s handling agent Swissport would be responsible for this. Once off the plane, another delay ensued at Immigration, which is run by the Home Office, where, Ian claims, â€˜two thirds of the automated gates were not workingâ€™. Immigration completed, Ian had high hopes for a smooth run to the door - but then came the baggage hall, a process which, again, is run by the airlineâ€™s handling agent Swissport. Ian said: â€œAt pm not a single bag had been delivered, a Tannoy announcement told us that, due to a shortage of staff, they had been unable to unload the aircraft. There were no further announcements and not a single member of staff in the building. He claimed a man in overalls and a high-viz jacket eventually appeared and seemed to examine the conveyor. But Swissport have denied this staff member works for them. It is unclear who they report to. He added: An elderly lady asked him when the baggage would appear. His response sums up the whole problem with Manchester airport. Succinctly, â€˜Its got f*** all to do with meâ€™.â€ Ian says his bag finally came into view at .pm - more than three hours after arrival. His flight from Italy took one hour and  minutes. It took three hours and  minutes to reclaim his baggage, he claims.  He claimed a man in overalls and a high-viz jacket eventually appeared and seemed to examine the conveyor. But Swissport have denied this staff member works for them. It is unclear who they report to. He added: An elderly lady asked him when the baggage would appear. His response sums up the whole problem with Manchester airport. Succinctly, â€˜Its got f*** all to do with meâ€™.â€ Ian says his bag finally came into view at .pm - more than three hours after arrival. His flight from Italy took one hour and  minutes. It took three hours and  minutes to reclaim his baggage, he claims. He says he understands the pressure Manchester Airport is under, but added: â€œI am angry about the airportâ€™s response to my enquiries.â€ â€œAt pm not a single bag had been delivered, a Tannoy announcement told us that, due to a shortage of staff, they had been unable to unload the aircraft. There were no further announcements and not a single member of staff in the building.  Customer Services only led to an an automated voice, while the head office number was met with â€˜this personâ€™s phone is switched offâ€™. He finally reached the press office and arranged a call back from a customer service supervisor who, Ian claims, â€˜refused to give their nameâ€™ and issued an â€˜insincere apologyâ€™, while explaining that the airport was â€˜not responsible for the problems he had experiencedâ€™. Ian was promised a call from a senior manager, which he says never happened, and has since sent emails to ious staff members, including MD Karen Smart, to no avail. â€œThis is my real complaint and it is symptomatic of the problems at Manchester Airport, they treat their customers with complete contempt. A Manchester Airport spokesman said: â€œWe are disappointed to hear Mr Langley was unhappy with his experience when ing through the airport. We are aware of challenges faced by our partners on the day in question, which led to service standards falling below what we want to see at Manchester Airport. This includes ground handling agents handling bags on behalf of airlines, and UK Border Force managing the immigration process. The whole of the industry is facing challenges associated with recovering from the biggest crisis it has faced in a generation, and while we understand the pressure this places on all partners operating at Manchester Airport, we will work with those concerned to understand the root cause of issues. â€œMr Langley raised his concerns with us on Monday morning and received a call from a complaints manager on the same day. We are aware he was unhappy with some elements of this response, and he has since had a second phone call from a senior team member to explore his concerns in greater detail. â€œWe take all feedback about our processes and service seriously, and have offered to have further discussions with him and members of his partyappropriate. At the same, we want to be clear that rude, abusive or offensive behaviour towards any of our colleagues will not be tolerated.â€ â€œWe would like apologise to the passengers who experienced delays disembarking and collecting baggage at Manchester Airport. We understand the frustration of passengers who have experienced this disruption and we are working hard with our partners to implement contingency measures to remedy these delays.â€ As international travel continues to reopen and passenger numbers rise, we have been clear that queue times may be longer as we ensure all passengers are compliant with the security and immigration measures put in place to keep us safe. title: people who feel unwell told
story: Anyone with a cold told to â€˜stay homeâ€™ under new guidance as free tests scrappedFree testing for the general public ends on Friday as part of the Living with Covid plan which last month set out the governmentâ€™s strategy to live with and manage the virusPeople who have a high temperature will be told to try and stay homeImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsPeople who feel unwell will be told to stay home and avoid contact with others after April  when free Covid tests are scrapped for most people. Free testing for the general public ends on Friday as part of the Living with Covid plan which last month set out the governmentâ€™s strategy to live with and manage the virus.From  April, updated guidance will advise people with symptoms of a respiratory infection, including Covid-, and a high temperature or who feel unwell, to try stay at home and avoid contact with other people, until they feel well enough to resume normal activities and they no longer have a high temperature, the Department of Health and Social Care says.Until this date, people should continue to follow the current guidance. Children and young people who are unwell and have a high temperature should also stay at home and avoid contact with other people, where they can. They can go back to school, college or childcare when they no longer have a high temperature, and they are well enough to attend.  From April , anyone with a positive Covid- test result will be advised to try to stay at home and avoid contact with other people for  days, which is when they are most infectious. Advice will be provided for iniduals who need to leave their home when they have symptoms or have tested positive, including avoiding close contact with people with a weakened immune system, wearing a face-covering and avoiding crowded places. Dame Jenny Harries, Chief Executive of the UK Health Security Agency, said: As we learn to live with Covid, we are focusing our testing provision on those at higher risk of serious outcomes from the virus, while encouraging people to keep following simple steps to help keep themselves and others safe. The pandemic is not over and how the virus will develop over time remains uncertain. Covid still poses a real risk to many of us, particularly with case rates and hospitalisations on the rise. That is why it is sensible to wear a mask in enclosed spaces, keep indoor spaces ventilated and stay away from othersyou have any symptoms of a respiratory illness, including Covid.  Vaccination remains the best way to protect us all from severe disease and hospitalisation due to Covid infection. If you have not yet come forward for your primary or booster I would urge you to do so straight away â€“ the NHS vaccine programme is there to help you and the sooner you are vaccinated the sooner you and your family and friends will be protected.Under the plans set out free symptomatic testing will be provided for: Patients in hospital, where a PCR test is required for their care and to provide access to treatments and to support ongoing clinical surveillance for new iants People who are eligible for community Covid- treatments because they are at higher risk of getting seriously ill from Covid-. People in this group will be contacted directly and sent lateral flow tests to keep at home for usethey have symptoms as well as being told how to reorder tests People living or working in some high-risk settings. For example, staff in adult social care services such as homecare organisations and care homes, and residents in care homes and extra care and supported living services, NHS workers and those working and living in hospices, and prisons and places of detention , where infection needs to be identied quickly to minimise outbreaks. People will also be tested before being discharged from hospital into care homes, hospices, homelessness settings and domestic abuse refuges. Asymptomatic lateral flow testing will continue from April in some high-risk settings where infection can spread rapidly while prevalence is high. This includes patient-facing staff in the NHS and NHS-commissioned Independent Healthcare Providers, staff in hospices and adult social care services, such as homecare organisations and care homes, a small number of care home visitors who provide personal care, staff in some prisons and places of detention and in high risk domestic abuse refuges and homelessness settings.Testing will be provided for residential SEND, care home staff and residents during an outbreak and for care home residents upon admission. This also includes some staff in prisons and immigration removal centres. story: Science teacher unable to get out of bed andto normal le due to Long CovidMany people who were key workers during the pandemic are still suffering due to Covid. Maya Gibbon, who was a science teacher, has been left mostly unable to get out of bed after catching the virusMaya Gibbon has been struggling to adjust to le with a chronic health conditionByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnistClaire Donnelly:,  Mar |comments Maya Gibbon was a busy science teacher at a Brighton secondary school two years ago. Since Â­contracting Covid in the classroom, she has been mostly unable to get out of bed, struggling to adjust to le with a chronic health condition.Unable to work, and with her husband now acting as her full-time carer, the couple were forced to live in a van for five months last year and are now facing homelessness again. â€œThis week is my two-year Covid Â­anniversary and I honestly feel like the person I was died two years ago,â€ Maya says. â€œI have stopped doing practically everything I did before.â€Antony Loveless and his partner Claire caught the virus in January  and have never recovered. At times, it has affected the couple so badly that Antony has even contemplated taking his own le. â€œWe had professional lives, we worked - hours a day, then came home, cooked dinner, did chores, we volunteered,â€ he says. â€œNow I struggle to make toast. Our le is in these four walls. We canâ€™t even use our car because we canâ€™t walk the few feet to get to it.â€ Saskia Mulder, , a deputy ward sister, living in Derry, Northern Ireland, caught Covid after caring for positive patients in March . She also says she has felt suicidal at times. â€œI thought Iâ€™d be better after a few weeks,â€ she says. â€œTwo years on Iâ€™m still off work, using a stick and have cognitive problems. Iâ€™m nowhere near the person I was, my mental health has suffered so much. Iâ€™m a strong person, but itâ€™s taken everything.â€ We are now told we must â€œlive withâ€ Covid. Yet for . million people with Long Covid, le over the last two years has changed unrecognisably â€“ with very little support. Many of these people were key workers who had to work while the rest of Britain kept safe. Many in the public sector were betrayed by the Governmentâ€™s failure on PPE. Yet, like the Covid bereaved, these people are now in danger of being forgotten by a government in whose interests it is to move on as quickly as possible from the virus.Today, in a moving debate called in Parliament, Layla Moran MP, Chair of the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Coronavirus, told those with Long Covid: â€œWe hear you. You have not been forgotten. And we continue to fight for you.â€ As well as a public health emergency, Moran warned of a â€œlooming crisis aheadâ€ for the economy with .% of the population affected. â€œPublic sector workers gave their lives,â€ she said. â€œWhen we were all allowed to be at home, they went in, and, according to the Office for National Statistics, are the ones who have the highest prevalence of Long Covid. I do believe we owe them so much more.â€Labour MP Debbie Abrahams spoke about her own experience of Long Covid, including â€œprolonged fatigue and nasty bouts of nausea,â€ as well as â€œworsened arthritis, pain that is sometimes completely debilitatingâ€.She raised the plight of , children with Long Covid as well as that of frontline workers and people in deprived communities more associated with the condition. â€œThis Covid pandemic is far from over,â€ she told the House.The APPG reports that the UK government has â€œcontinuously failedâ€ to take Long Covid into account and has not â€œadequately fundedâ€ research into treatment. Antony Loveless goes further. â€œThey have blood on their hands,â€ he says. â€œThey are wilfully ignoring it. I had to sit and listen to Rishi Sunak talking about writing off Â£.billion of fraudulent business loans when thereâ€™s only Â£million put forward to Long Covid support. Itâ€™s loose change to them, isnâ€™t it â€While Downing Street partied, Maya Gibbon has been living a new le of chronic illness and hospital appointments. She has had four hospital admissions, two operations, more than  blood tests, eight MRIs,  CT scans, two lumbar punctures,  ultrasounds, one colonoscopy, and multiple ECGs. Sheâ€™s had thunderclap headaches that make her black out, and kidney stones caused by her medication. story: Two Giant Galapagos tortoises born for first time in UK zoo thanks to randy -year-oldDirk, a -year-old tortoise, successfully mated with -year-old female Charlie last November. The eggs she laid resulted in the arrival of two tortoises at Crocodiles of the World in Brize Norton, OxonThe two babies and -year-old Dirk Image: MaxWillcock BNPSByAdam AspinallNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Two Giant Galapagos tortoises have been born for the first time in a British zoo thanks to a randy geriatric tortoise named Dirk.Despite being well over -years-old Dirk is still in peak physical condition and has a very healthy labido. He successfully mated with -year-old female Charlie last November and the eggs she laid have now resulted in the arrival of two tiny tortoises at Crocodiles of the World in Brize Norton, Oxon.It is the first time a British zoo has successfully bred a Giant Galapagos tortoise that is an endangered species.And despite their tiny size - they are about the size of a tennis ball and weigh about ozs each - they will grow to  stones each as adults. Giant Galapagos tortoises are famous for their long necks and are synonymous with Charles Darwin who discovered the theory of evolution by studying them.  The arrival of two baby tortoises is good news for the species whose numbers in the world now stand at about , compared to , in the th century. They are classed as vulnerable on the IUCNaposs Red List. Keepers at Crocodiles of the World are closely monitoring their progress and feeding them a diet of dried grasses, leafy greens, pear cactus and weeds. Shaun Foggett, founder of Crocodiles of the World, said: Weaposre incredibly proud to have successfully bred these tortoises, who have previously been very close to extinction. We have all been hoping for this day since the giant tortoises joined us in  and itaposs a signicant achievement towards helping the conservation of the species. The attraction has four adult Giant Galapagos tortoises three females called Zuzu, Isabella and Charlie and Dirk, who is named after lothario Dirk Diggler from the movie Boogie Nights. They are part of a European conservation programme. Dirk originally came to Britain after being caught from the wild on the Galapagos Islands in . Giant Galapagos tortoises - Chelonoidis niger in Latin - are the largest tortoise species in the world they can grow up to ft inand lbs in weight. They mate all year round and the male is known to make loud grunting noises when doing so. story: UK weather: Exact date cold temperatures will end to make way for heatwave in AprilMet Office Meteorologist Annie Shuttleworth said the warm temperatures over recent days were something of a â€œ startâ€ to the new seasonTemperatures are expected to get back up into the double digits next week Image: Getty ImagesByAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsThe icy conditions that have had Brits pulling out the winter woollies again this week will soon make way for â€œabove averageâ€ temperatures throughout April. While temperatures may not quite be getting back to the C that graced parts of the UK just days ago, forecasters say temperatures will be back in the double digits soon enough.Speaking to The Mirror, Met Office Meteorologist Annie Shuttleworth said the warm temperatures over recent days were something of a â€œ startâ€ to the new season. â€œThe temperatures we saw last week were well above the average temperature for late March across the UK,â€ she said. â€œSo it may have felt like summer for some but in fact it is still early spring when the average temperature is around  or  C in the UK.â€ Cold arctic air has brought colder temperatures, which would stick around over the weekend, Ms Shuttleworth said. story: I was dying for seven years and didnt realise - my organs were shutting downIvy Adelle, , from San Francisco, US, began feeling severely unwell as a teenager, but it took seven years for her to be finally diagnosed with systemic lupusIvy Adelle struggled with excruciating symptoms for seven years before being diagnosed Image: Jam PressByAmy WaltersRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA young woman was dying for seven years as her organs slowly shutdown - but she had no idea. Ivy Adelle was eventually diagnosed with a rare blood disorder after experiencing gruelling symptoms.The -year-old estate agent from San Francisco, US, first began feeling unwell as a teenager. At  she became very weak and noticed her stomach starting to swell. She ignored the signs of illness despite experiencing frequent nausea and seeing her urine change to the colour of cola. Ivy got her period at the beginning of that school year but two months later she realised she hadnapost had another. Have you been through a similar experience to Ivy  Let us know at webnews@mirrorEventually, she became so fatigued she would often fall asleep during lessons. She only began to panic when she had a period at the end of the school year and the blood was a blackish colour. â€œI was fearful, I thought I had cancer or something was really wrong with me,â€ she said. Ivy was scared to go to the doctors because it was expensive and she didnapost want to burden her parents, in case she was actually fine and just overreacting. She put her struggles to focus at school down to her own lack of care or that she wasnapost trying hard enough.Ivy knew that girls sometimes stop having periods due to amenorrhea and because she was a little underweight assumed that was the reason.â€œI felt like I had sandbags all over my body, as well as severe headaches and bouts of mood swings, loss of appetite and some minor pains, she explained.Her stomach also became somewhat large and felt stf and continued to get worse until she was hospitalised four weeks later. That summer - June  - Ivy fainted in front of her parents and she was rushed to hospital via ambulance.At first, she was told that she had an eating disorder as she was pale and her blood sugar was low. But doctors soon found that she was actually suffering from organ failure and was at risk of dying. Ivy said: â€œI was shocked to realise I was dying and this is what slow death felt like. She described herself as very much out of it due to her low blood levels and the news was pretty terrying. Doctors told Ivy to call her closest friends and family but she felt upset and angry as well as numb due to the severe pain.  She said: â€œI felt like I was being punished by le and I wanted to enjoy my friends and family - I was so young. Ivy was diagnosed with auto-immune haemolytic anaemia along with cold agglutinins disease and antiphospholipid syndrome.But at the time, they didnapost realise it was caused by systemic lupus, as testing can take several years.Finally, in June , Ivy was diagnosed with lupus - where the immune system attacks healthy tissues and organs.Auto-immune haemolytic disease is a rare red blood cell disorder that produces antibodies to destroy these cells and is coupled with cold agglutinins â€“ the onset â€“ as well as antiphospholipid syndrome, which causes the antibodies by mistake. It is believed that the blood disease was a result of Ivyâ€™s undiagnosed lupus, coupled with severe amounts of stress. As she needed a blood transfusion immediately, she was flown to a hospital in Sacramento, Calornia, which has specialists in the disease. Ivy said it was a race against time to find a blood match.  Usually blood for a transfusion is heated up but there was such a rush they had to put it in cold. Her best friend brought Ivyaposs mum and sisters to visit her in the hospital - an act of kindness Iaposll never forget, she added. Constant testing and drugs continued, but Ivy said sometimes this didnapost even touch it. â€œI wouldnâ€™t laugh or smile because my body was in an immense amount of pain, but my brain hurt far worse than my body, she said. Ivy went on to do a lot of deep digging and cognitive behavioural therapy to help her cope. She felt it was important to have mental clarity and seek forgiveness for the things that have affected me. Her blood disease has stayed in remission, though Ivy did fall ill again around four years ago and it has taken a long time to recover again. Her lupus flared up severely and she was treated with the wrong drug which caused her to go into anaphylaxis, she explained. She couldnapost breathe and was put on an intense treatment programme. Ivy still suffers from chronic pain and has since developed fibromyalgia â€“ a long-term condition which causes pain all over the body â€“ after a car accident. As this causes sensory issues for her skin, she has to be careful about the clothes she wears and as she also has many food allergies, she is very mindful about the food she eats. â€œMy goal is to figure out all the factors that trigger this and share my journey with others, she said. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. title: new glamping site set to open in the cairngorms national park
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. title: gardening tips the start of autumn 2 2 2 2 2
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowThe garden really comes alive in April and the number of tasks to be carried out is considerable.Making the best use of the ening days is a bonus and, providing the weather stays fair, it can be a brilliant gardening month.In addition to dead-heading spring bulbs, now is the time to get planting so why not think about one or two new additions to your garden that will make you feel really happy.A survey carried out at the Cha Flower Show identied the top three plants in the UK that are most likely to put a smile on your face â€“ lily of the valley, sweet pea and jasmine # so they might make good additions to your garden this year.Lily of the valley is very low maintenance, easy to grow and can be planted in borders or underneath a tree.They make good ground cover for shady spots and are beautully fragrant with creamy white bell-shaped nodding flowersÂ  # but be warned they are toxic to dogs, cats and children.Sweet peas, with their frilly, delicate and often sweetly fragrant flower heads, are available in a huge iety of bright and pastel colours. They work well in a sunny or partially shaded area in fertile well-drained soil.Climbing jasmine can be highly scented, with ieties that flower in summer and winter. All produce pretty flowers and are fairly easy to grow against walls or up trellis.There are some fun options for kids to plant such as sunflowers, snapdragons and the four o#clock flower.If you look at a sunflower, you canâ€™t help but smile. Not only does it remind us of the sun, but its head will track the sun through the sky.Snapdragons are great because they come in a iety of colours and sizes, and you can pinch the blossoms so they open and shut just like a dragonâ€™s mouth.Snapdragon flowers are specically designed for bumblebees, which are just the right weight to trip the opening mechanism of the lower lip of the flower to gain access to the nectar.The four o#clock flower, also known as the marvel of Peru, is a bushy plant with trumpet-shaped flowers in shades of pink, yellow or white.The fragrant flowers donâ€™t open until late afternoon, around four oâ€™clock # so they are good for telling the time.If you are growing your own vegetables, now is a good time to start sowing tomatoes, so you can enjoy them throughout the summer.You will need rich, fertile soil or peat-free potting compost, and a good sunny, sheltered spot. Water regularly and feed regularly once the plants start to flower.Tomatoes are split into two main growing types # bush and cordon. Bush types are usually planted in containers and their stems trail around the edge. Cordon types are trained to grow tall, supported by a cane or stake and will require pinching out.Growing tomatoes from seed is best done under cover, into seed trays, then when the seedlings get to -cm tall transplant to small cm pots. Keep potting on as they grow in size.They can be planted outside with cane supports once the last frosts have gone, so around May time.For best results, choose trusted ieties like Gardener#s Delight, Money Maker or Sweet Olive.As usual, April really kick-starts the gardening season.According to the Royal Horticultural Society, spring is finally in evidence as daffodils and flowering trees start to bloom. Expect the inevitable April showers but with sunny days too, when you can turn your attention to the lawn.It#s an exciting month, with indoor-sown seeds well into growth, and it#s also time to start sowing outdoors. Just watch out for frosts.Top three jobs this month:

title: mozart to jazz trio ecossaise delight ardrishaig
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowMid Argyll Arts Associationwas delighted to welcome Trio Ecossaise as guest performers at Ardrishaig Public Hall for the fourth concert of the season.The impact of Covid has meant that many planned concerts had to be cancelled or dates changed so it was wonderful to have Trio Ecossaise perform on March .The concert opened with the Kegelstatt Trio by Mozart. Much of the chamber music that Mozart composed was music for friends to perform and this trio is just one of these.Originally composed for clarinet, viola and piano, the viola part can be performed on cello as Harriet ably demonstrated. Very typically Mozart # easy to listen to and thoroughly enjoyable.On to the Craftsbury Trio, written by the American Gwyneth Walker. This trio has four movements, each depicting the small town of Craftsbury, Vermont.Up Country Toccata, The Lark in the Morning, You Can Buy It at the General Store, to the final movement Craftsbury Common depicting the green with a white picket fence.The movements are as descriptive as their titles and show many dferent skills on all instruments # fluttering sounds, jazz harmonies, numerous glissandos, syncopation, decorations and finishing with gentle rhythmic tapping.There is even a hint of Rhapsody in Blue in the third movement. If you only listen to one piece again this is the one and should be seen live,possible, and not just listened to.Rachmaninovâ€™s Prelude in B minor for solo piano was Claireâ€™s choice for the programme.This prelude, The Bell was Rachmaninovâ€™s own favourite and was the one that he would often perform. The audience was delighted to be introduced to it by Claire.Brahms composed four chamber works which featured the clarinet later in le after a period when he wasnâ€™t writing anything at all.This was the third trio of the evening and was again very dferent in style allowing Jenner , Harrietand Claireto demonstrate their considerable skills as a trio to a very appreciative audience.An arrangement of Consolation No. by Liszt for Trio Ecossaise was their encore.This was the second visit by Trio, and it is only a matter of time before they are welcomed back.There are two MAAA concerts planned for April # The Willow Trioand the Ugly Bug Ragtime Three. Keep an eye on the Argyllshire Advertiser for details.

story: WORLD-CLASS road cycling willto the Scottish Borders this year when the area hosts the prestigious Tour of Britain and Tour Series events.Galashiels will welcome Britainâ€™s leading male and female cyclists when it hosts the Tour Series, the fun, free and family-friendly cycling event, on Wednesday  May.Launched in , the series sees Britainâ€™s best male and female riders compete against each other in a unique, team-based format as part of a full day of sporting and community-focused activities.British sporting heroes Laura Kenny, Tom Pidcock, Dani Rowe, Joanna Rowsell, Ed Clancy, Elinor Barker and Katie Archibald have all competed in the series during its history.Gala will become the sixth Scottish host venue with this new-for- round taking place on a technical circuit that starts and finishes adjacent to the idyllic Bank Street gardens.Riders will also pass by the Burgh Chambers and War Memorial, and the Great Tapestry of Scotland Visitor Centre during the one-kilometrelap that twists its way through the town.Stage two of the Tour of Britain â€“ the UKâ€™s most prestigious cycle race â€“ will then take place solely within the Scottish Borders on Monday  September.The Borders have previously welcomed the race on eight occasions, including a stage start in Hawick last year, as well as a stage that started and finished in Kelso in .Mick Bennett, Tour of Britain and Tour Series race director said: â€œFew places lend themselves more to cycling than the Scottish Borders, owing to the mix of historic, unforgettable towns and stunning countryside roads. To be able to take the Tour Series there for the first time andwith the Tour of Britain once again shows the appetite for our world-famous events in the area. My gratitude goes out to everybody at the Scottish Borders Council for their continued support, dedication and passion.â€Sam Smith, Scottish Borders Councilâ€™s Chief Officer for Economic Development added: â€œWe are delighted to be able to bring back the Tour of Britain to the Borders again this year, and to be hosting a round of the televised Tour Series for the first time too..removeâ€œThese will be fantastic occasions for the area and will bring in visitors and provide great exposure for the Borders, further strengthening our position as Scotlandâ€™s leading cycling destination.â€œIâ€™d like to thank our partners Live Borders and Energise Galashiels for their support in bringing the Tour Series to Galashiels and their commitment to help make it an amazing event for the community and visitors.â€Highlights of both the menâ€™s and womenâ€™s Tour Series races will once again be broadcast on ITV.

story: A BORDERS farm site is to provide a home away from home for touristsÂ after a bid for three glamping pods was rubber-stamped.Scottish Borders Councilhas agreed an application from Mr and Mrs Mykura for the use of land north east of Bogbank Farmhouse in Coldingham.A statement with the application says rural businesses increasingly require a erse range of activities to ensure profitability, as tourism and leisure become evermore important parts of a countryside business, and agricultural incomes are unpredictable.The statement adds: â€œThe addition of hospitality accommodation to the traditional farm activities will promote access to the countryside and provide high quality, sustainable development.
