title: leader march 11 2022
story: One of the five tenets of taekwon-do is indomitable spirit.That is something which has been displayed in abundance in the last two weeks, since Russian forces invaded Ukraine.Despite all they are currently facing, Ukrainian soldiers took time on Tuesday, on International Women#s Day, to hand flowers to women they stopped at checkpoints.Viral videos of off-duty Ukrainian soldiers dancing in their unorms continue to flood social media.And, amid leading the fight against Russian invaders and holding meetings with world leaders, the country#s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, welcomed the start of spring in an outdoors video, ending the broadcast with a wink to the camera.The strength of spirit Ukrainians continue to show, from the bottom to the very top, should be an inspiration to us all.Kintyre has already shown incredible community spirit in its response to the crisis â€“ well done to every person who contributed.And, although it might not effect change on a global scale, SG Taekwon-Do#s display of support for Ukraine shows that there are people in every corner of the world willing to stand up for democracy and what they believe is right.

title: letters march 11 2022
story: The Campbeltown Courier printed a story in February  about a painting, Village in the Valley, by H Shapiro.A reader then wrote to you, letting you know that the painting was by Hyman Shapiro and informed you that he had three children.I am one of Hyman Shapiro#s granddaughters. He had five children, not three.Before he was married to Gretl, the potter mentioned in the reader#s letter, he had two daughters, Gladys and Ruth, by his first we, Margaret, who died of tuberculosis.My mother Ruth, like her father, is a talented artist who has exhibited paintings.My we had to call the emergency services for me last Friday night at .am and,  minutes later, an ambulance arrived and the two paramedics provided me with great care and attention before transporting me to Campbeltown Hospital.I would like to thank them for the care and attention given to me.They do not receive as much gratitude from the public as they should and I would like to put on record my heartfelt thanks for their dedication and help in a very stressful period.Do the people of Campbeltown and her surrounding South Kintyre communities truly believe local frustrations are being heard in Kilmory Or have our three sitting councillors been napping this past decade, resting on their laurels, in the belief they are unaccountable to voters.It has been  years since the people of South Kintyre have voted in a local election. If you want to continue having the same conversations, raising the same issues, exasperated with the same results, thenthe same trio at the polls on May  and expect the same for the next five years.As a young man, I made a commitment to serve my country as a Royal Marines Commando now, I am prepared to make that same commitment to my community.I promise to proudly serve the people of South Kintyre to the best of my ability and present a strong new Conservative Unionist voice.If we do not meet on the doorstep in the coming months, can I encourage you to make your mark, on May , for a positive change to South Kintyre#s immediate future.I write after thousands of pounds worth of educational books were thrown in the bin in Oban.It is essential that our council#s leadership makes sure that hard-pressed council taxpayers are being provided with value for money. This in my opinion is a prime example of a failure to do so.The council leader talks a great deal about environmentalism but how is this environmental This is particularly saddening given the fact that so many teachers often struggle for ample educational booklets.My constituents are asking why our council taxes are having to go up when mountains of perfectly good books are being thrown in the skip It is beyond belief that this can be allowed to happen. These expensive books could be put to much better use than this.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022
story: Who am I  What am I  Where am I  How am I  â€“ questions of identity and some of the questions I was left asking when I left a recent meeting.That meeting was part of a world-wide movement â€“ a movement that calls the peoples of the world to pray.Similar questions of identity were raised when I was asked to write â€˜a pieceâ€™ for this newspaper. The questions werenâ€™t so much about me but you â€“ who are you  What are you  Where are you  And how are you I can answer the questions about â€˜meâ€™ relatively easily, knowing that others might disagree. But I cannot so easily answer such questions about you for I donâ€™t really know who reads this column.Identity, human identity, all of us wrestle with questions of identity â€“ from the inidual to a community to a nation or a race.Who are the Scots  Who are the Ukrainians  Who are the Russians  Where do you come from The answers are never as simple as we think they might be or would like them to be.Humanity is such a erse and multi-faceted part of creation.In recent weeks, many have tried to understand why the world finds itself on the potential tipping point of another large-scale war.In part, it is to do with identity â€“ a simplication, I know â€“ and a greed for power, land and wealth.Doomsters will shake their heads and wring their hands in despair, offering little hope.Politicians will talk and negotiate and may God bless them as they do!What will you do Your response will reflect something of your identity.Will you identy with a world-wide movement and pray for the well-being of the world

title: from our files friday march 18
story: Friday March  Gigha was alive yesterday, Thursday, as people travelled to join in the celebrations for its th anniversary of community ownership.Campbeltown Junior Pipe Band piped the children from the local primary school down the main road to the hotel to emphasise the change in the number of children on the island.The children donned their new unorms to mark the occasion, carrying the Gigha flag.Fundraising has been ongoing over a period of time to raise cash towards the celebrations.To date more than Â£, has been raised, and events have included a race night, celebrations at New Year, and a quiz night.Last night islanders gathered for the ceilidh to bring the celebrations to a close.TWENTY FIVE YEARS AGOFriday March  Argyllâ€™s newest nursing home was officially opened in Campbeltown.The Â£, Kintyre Nursing Home, which is situated in Hall Street overlooking Campbeltown Loch, was formally opened by Councillor George McMillan.Speaking during the opening of the new home, Mr McMillan said thatthe care in the home was as good as the building itself, no one would have anything to worry about.He went on to explain that getting the home build have not always been an easy task.â€˜There were some dficulties about the site because of the ground conditions but there were also other problems with the planners about this site because itâ€™s a very prominent site and itâ€™s next door to some very fine buildings on the left-hand side.â€˜It was a problem getting the plan is to agree to the ious shapes and types of materials that were to be used, but we overcame all these things and got the go-ahead.â€™FIFTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Popular local turf accountant, Mr Hugh McKellar, has won a holiday for two in Majorca in a raffle organised by Tarbert Football Club.Mr McKellar did not even know he had won the prize. For he threw away the tickets he had bought, thinking that the dance at which the winning ticket was to be drawn had been held.But, unbeknown to him, the fuel crisis meant that thewas postponed for a week.When told he had won the prize, Mr McKellar was flabbergasted.â€˜It was the biggest surprise of my le. And Iâ€™ve had a few,â€™ he told a Courier man later.Mr McKellar and his we, Christine, both bought tickets. They are still arguing over who won the prize!Mr and Mrs McKellar live with their family at  Ralston Road Campbeltown.SEVENTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Refloated by Campbeltown LeboatAfter the tow-rope had parted in one attempt, the crew of the Campbeltown leboat, City of Glasgow were lucky in the third venture, when, on a two-and-a-half hour ebb tide, they pulled off the  tons Glasgow coaster Saint Kentigern, which had run aground, bow on, on a ledge of rock on the notorious Patersonâ€™s reef, off the island of Sanda, Mull of Kintyre, in dense fog, on Monday night.The leboat put to see at : pm in response to news from Mr John Macintyre, Lady Mary Row, a member of the leboat crew, who, listening on the short wave, picked up a radio message from the distressed coaster that she was in dficulties and required leboat assistance.The fog had come down suddenly in the late evening and conditions were very thick when the leboat nosed out of Campbeltown Loch and around Davaar.There was a slight breeze and the sea was almost comparatively calm.Standing by, just over six cables away from the coaster, was the Ardchattan of  tons, also belonging to Mrs J and a Gardner and Company,  Clyde Street, Glasgow.Near at hand was the Burns-Laird cargo steamer, Lairdsdale, which had erted course while en-route to Londonderry, to stand-by. Also standing by was the steamer Brora, which was bund for Belfast.The conditions were so bad from the point of view of visibility that the leboat had to receive bearings from the Brora and other ships by means of the Aldis signal lamps while shipsâ€™ searchlights assisted them in getting into position. For a time the ships could only see each other on the radar screen.Coxswain Duncan Newlands, who knows this dreaded part of the estuary like the back of his hand, edged his leboat in astern of the coaster and proceeded to begin operations, but at .am came this dramatic message over the leboatâ€™s radio: â€˜Arrived alongside casualty at .hours got rope aboard and commenced towing at . hours.â€˜Rope now parted. Returning alongside St Kentigern for further instructions.â€™There was a lull in the activities while the leboat resumed its operations. They tried again- without success.Then came the news at . hours â€“ â€˜St Kentigern Refloated.â€™The leboat has succeeded in its third attempt, against odds.The St Kentigern then proceeded to Campbeltown under her own power, while the leboat escorted her, but first it took in tow the coasterâ€™s own leboat, which it had earlier lowered over the port side in case of an emergency.The Ardchattern also accompanied the Saint Kentigern to Campbeltown.Meantime, the two remaining ships, Lairdsdale and Brora, seeing their attendance was no longer required, sent a parting signal of good-luck to the coaster and continued on their respective passages to towards the Irish Coast.

story: With some fishermen enduring three weeks of no income and a further eight weeks until the current ban on fishing in the Clyde Recovery Box comes to an end, it was fantastic to see that Argyll and Bute MSP Jenni Minto has lobbied the Minister for Rural Affairs Mairi Gougeon to get financial assistance to help the fishers through this dficult time.Not surprisingly, the Scottish Government have still refused any assistance.At a meeting of the Rural Affairs, Island and Natural Environment Committee on Wednesday March  a vote was taken on whether to annul the ban on fishing in the recovery box.Sadly the MSP for Argyll and Bute decided to look after her own pay packet, political career and tow the line with her Nationalist colleagues to support the ban on fishing in the area.This caused fellow committee member Scottish Conservative Rachel Hamilton to suggest backbenchers, with reference to Ms Minto, are #spineless#.Having deserted the local fishermen, their families and supporting businesses Ms Minto has shown yet another example of Nationalist MSPs being afraid to rock the boat in Holyrood.The Scottish Government has banned creel fishing in parts of the Clyde as part of a plan to protect cod.It was pointed out to our MSP Jenny Minto that:.Â Â Â Â The bodies campaigning for this ban did NOT want or need creel fishermen included for the protection of baby cod..Â Â Â Â The scientic advice was modied to exclude creel fishing. Baby young cod are not caught in prawn creels. The scientists at the Rural Affairs Committee meeting on March  said that there was zero evidence for creels to be included in the ban, and that the previous evidence cited on the Scottish Government website had now been removed.Our MSP represented to the creel fishermen in Campbeltown that she would:.Â Â Â Â Seek a relaxation of the ban to enable the creel fishermen to continue to work as per the scientic evidence advice..Â Â Â Â Seek compensation for the creel fishermen for almost three months loss of income.However, in the event she VOTED.Â Â Â Â To keep the ban in place.Â Â Â Â Against compensation.This is absolutely duplicitous. Please visitÂ marysmeals.org.ukÂ to find out more about our appeal.The children of South Sudan arenâ€™t giving up. And nor are we. We know that no child on this earth is unreachable.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022 2
story: As our planet continues its journey around the sun we notice that theIt is not so dark in the morning and the daylight is extending in the evening. In other words, we are leaving winter behind and spring is around the corner.Although winter brings dark days it also has wonderful surprises on clear nights when the stars seem to dance in the sky and with planets making appearances from time to time.However we must focus on spring. That is where we are just now. This isTrusting from previous years we plant seeds in the knowledge that they will probably germinate and grow into plants before too long. Itâ€™s all an amazing process as new le forms.Are the churches still living in dark days or are there signs of new le  Alas in so many places it looks like the former with declining membership rolls and constant struggles to keep going. story: I would like to take this opportunity to clary my position regarding the forthcoming council election.After  years in office, my position has somewhat changed, as was well documented in the Campbeltown Courier in October .Despite myself and numerous constituents querying the decision taken, a satisfactory explanation has still not been provided.As readers will know, I always stand up for my local community at every turn and put South Kintyre first, rather than toeing the party line, when council decisions are made.I am of the opinion that this is the reason for the decision that was taken last year. title: calls for strong action against planning violations
story: Councillor Rory Colville sought reassurance that the authority would take serious action against unauthorised work after the council published a draft of its new enforcement and monitoring charter.A council official reaffirmed part of the charter which said that enforcement was intended to resolve a problem, rather than punish a mistake.The discussion took place during a virtual meeting of the authorityâ€™s planning, protective services and licensing committee on Wednesday, March .Councillor Colville said: #I want to seek reassurance, because reading about enforcement, it seems to lack any teeth.#We are almost bending over backwards to work with those abusing their position.#Can you assure us that we do take strong action when it is required #Council planning officer Peter Bain replied: #We do take breaches seriously. Our approach in the charter very much aligns with the Scottish Governmentâ€™s planning legislation.#It is not intended to be a punishment â€“ it recognises that development is capable of gaining consent and being brought under control.#But where we have developments which are unacceptable, we would expect to act with the power that is required.#Councillor Colville then asked: #Is there any indication of officer time which is taken up  Is this a drain on our resources #Mr Bain responded: #It can be. We have an underlying enforcement caseload, as there are minor breaches of control which take an element of officersâ€™ time, to take retrospective applications and serve notices.#We have a resource of two full-time officers and we are facilitating enforcement by drawing on planning officer time.#When we get signicant breaches of control, that will give rise to resources we donâ€™t have on hand. We need to ert resources to deal with them because they are time-critical to deal with the parties involved.#The charter, circulated in advance of the meeting, states: #Planning permission is required for most development that takes place in Scotland, with the exception of some minor works.#However, developers or householders sometimes undertake work without planning permission or fail to comply with the terms of planning permissions.#The purpose of planning enforcement is to resolve a problem rather than to punish a mistake. Any action taken has to be appropriate to the scale of the breach.#Councils have discretionary powers to enforce planning controls in such cases,they consider it is in the public interest and expedient to do so having regard to a deemed assessment against the Local Development Plan and material planning considerations.#Councils also monitor certain developments to ensure planning controls are being followed. Additionally, the public often alert the council to problems they become aware of.#

title: port-seton-womans-dogs-win-big-crufts
story: Erin Inverarity, a Crufts veteran having competed at the world recognised competition for seven years, was thrilled and excited when her two beloved dogs, four-year-old Springer Spaniel and Border Collie mix Neve and eight-year-old Springer Spaniel Sam, ed home to East Lothian from the NEC in Birmingham with a rosette each at the beginning of the month.Crufts, an international television event, attracts around , competitors alongside hundreds of thousands of visitors each year.Organised by the Kennel Club, the annual canine event takes place over four days and celebrates dogs from across the globe.Erin has had a love for the four legged pets for years and even set up a dog grooming business, Erins Doggy Day Care, in Port Seton almost four years ago.She explained the process of the categories Neve and Sam competed in, saying: "I compete my dogs in agility which requires the dogs to complete a course of up to  obstacles."I travel all over Britain to gain points and to advance through the competing grading system â€“ grade  being beginners and grade  being advanced."The young Kennel Club is open to dog handlers under the age of  and the other is open to any age of dog handler."The open category is most commonly known for being shown on tv."The former Preston Lodge High School student said it was a "massive surprise" to her when her young dog Neve, whom she rescued from Ireland when the pup was just four months old, placed so highly.She continued: "This was Neves first time at Crufts and she competed in the Young Kennel Club Graduate Agility."This event is only eligible for beginner dogs grade -."She placed first in - year old Graduate Agility event and won the overall Graduate Agility over all age groups."Her other dog Sam, a regular at Crufts, competed in the open event called ABC.She said: "This stands for anything but Collies and consists of two rounds."Jumping, made up of jumps and tunnels and agility made up of contact frames."After the two rounds, the overall score is combined to have an overall winner."In the jumping round Sam finished fth and the agility round he finished second, which meant overall we finished second."She was congratulated by a number of people on social media following her success, with one commenter saying: "None of this surprises us - title: covid-scotland-facemask-law-indoor-settings-remains-easter-monday
story: From Easter Monday on April , the mask mandate will be downgraded to guidance for hospitality, retail, public transport, and other indoor settingsÂ  - such as hairdressers, gyms, and cinemas -Â for the first time since summer .The rules will be relaxed earlier, from Monday April , for some other settings such as places of worship and wedding or funeral ceremonies, however.Nicola Sturgeon said continuing to require facemasks by law for a further two weeks struck a "sensible balance" amid signs that the BA. Omicron wave in Scotland is beginning to peak or stabilise.The number of people in hospital with Covid fell from , to , in the past  hours The Covid threat level is expected to be reduced from medium to low during Spring, said the First Minister.Ms Sturgeon said: "This phased approach strikes a sensible balance between our desire to remove this one remaining legal measure, and the common sense need for continued caution - not least for the sake of the NHS - while this wave of infection subsides."I recognize that face coverings are an inconvenience. However, given all the sacrice of the past two years, and in view of the current pressure on the NHS, I believe the vast majority of people will accept that for a further two weeks this is a proportionate precautionary measure while we pass the peak of this latest wave."It also provides some further protection to those who are most at risk from the virus."Compulsory face coverings have already come to an end in all other parts of the UK, with England - which briefly reintroduced them in December as part of its Plan B response to the Omicron wave - becoming the first to drop the requirement at the end of January.Â Â #COVID infections continued to increase across England, Wales and Scotland in the most recent week, but decreased in Northern Ireland.These high infection levels are driven by the Omicron BA. iant https:t.co zjZZxROXBX pic CSjbiIxMÂ In February, Northern Ireland switched facemasks from law to guidance, but still strongly advises the public to wear them in enclosed public spaces such as shops, bars, restaurants and public transport.Since Monday, people in Wales have no longer been required to wear facemasks in shops and on public transport, but they are still mandatory in health and care settings.Â The latest surveillance by the Office for National Statistics Â indicates that the prevalence of Covid is highest in Scotland - withÂ one in  people infected -Â despite the ongoing mask law.Â The next surveillance figures will be released on Friday.Surgical and cottonÂ masks are known to be less effective against the highly transmissible BA. Omicron strain than previous iants, although FFP and FFP masks remain protective.Â Ms Sturgeon said the Scottish Governments decision to delay the lting of the mask law across the board from Monday was taken to protect the NHS.Â She said: "WeÂ have taken account of the very high level of infection and the pressure on the NHS, and the fact that face coverings do provide an important layer of protection against transmission of the virus from one person to another."However, we are also mindful that the data may now be indicating a peaking of this wave of infection which should hopefully become more pronounced over the next couple of weeks."Source: Public Health ScotlandIt comes as weekly data showed a dip in Covid hospital admissions for the first time since the BA. Omicron wave took off in February, with , Covid positive patients admitted in the week ending March  compared to , during the previous week.Â Notably, the decline was most pronounced - down by %, from  to  - in the over-s age group who are more likely to be sick as a result of Covid and take longer to recover, impacting on bed occupancy.Â Among the under-s, admissions continued to climb, but these are more likely to be incidental Covid cases where patients are in hospital for other reasons.Â There were  Covid admissions for patients under , of which were children aged five and under who are not currently eligible for Covid vaccinations.Â The number of people currently in hospital with Covid - which reflects both admissions and s of stay - also fell signicantly for the first time since February, from , to ,.Â The majority are not in hospital with Covid as a primary diagnosis, but still require to be isolated which squeezes hospital capacity and results in delays to operations.However, Ms Sturgeon told MSPs that there are "grounds for optimism that this latest wave of infection may now have peaked".Â She pointed to daily data from testing which shows aÂ % fall in confirmed cases over the last sevenÂ days which is "fairly consistent across all age groups", along with the findings from wastewater sampling which "also gives some cause for optimism".Â "It is not yet indicating a fall in the level of infection - but it does suggest that the situation has stabilised since mid March," said the First Minister.Â She added: "We will therefore continue to assess the data closely â€“ including, of course, the results of the latest ONS survey due later this week."But we are hopeful that this wave has peaked or is now peaking. Indeed, this is being observed already in Northern Ireland which, unlike England and Wales, appears to have been ahead of Scotland in the transmission of BA.."

title: tesco-north-berwick-bird-lovers-organise-boycott

title: graeme-macrae-burnet-shares-new-novel
story: For the bookworms among us, authors are the rock stars. As music fans lost their gigs at the height of the pandemic, avid readers also lost their author events and book festivals. And like musicians, authors lost that valuable connection with their audiences and the opportunity to promote new releases.When Case Study, the latest novel by Graeme Macrae Burnet was released last October, things were looking up â€“ Omicron was yet to come.â€œOf course events are the leblood of getting a book in front of the public and I did get a chance to do a few,â€ says Graeme. â€œSome of them were very last minute, however, because people werenâ€™t really committing â€“ they didnâ€™t know how many people could be invited. For events like Waterstones in Glasgow, the restriction in numbers meant we split the event over two nights.â€ Case Study is Graeme Macrae Burnetâ€™s fourth novel. His first, The Disappearance of AdÃ¨le Bedeau in  is set in small-town France and introduced the detective Georges Gorski. It is far from the typical detective novel.His second, from , is the book that thrust Graeme into the public eye with its shortlisting for the Booker Prize. The backdrop to His Bloody Project is a brutal triple murder in a remote Scottish Highland community during the s. The third, in , saw theof Georges Gorski The Accident on the A in the same setting as AdÃ¨le Bedeau.Case Study, which is published in paperback on April , heads to London in the s and what could be described as the â€œanti-psychiatryâ€ movement. A woman who believes a psychotherapist has driven her sister to suicide becomes a patient of his under a  name to seeher suspicions are true. The novel is told through notebooks and observations, drawing the reader deeper into this world and the relationship. Itâ€™s much more amusing, in places, than this makes it sound. Whatâ€™s clear, however is Graeme Macrae Burnet isnâ€™t an author who can be stuck in any genreâ€™s pigeonhole.All of Graemeâ€™s books have been published by Saraband , a company that formed in Connecticut in the s, relocated to Scotland in  and moved to Salford in .The attention that a book like His Bloody Project brings an author will inevitably be a large blip on the radar of much larger international publishers, but as Graeme explains there are many factors to take into consideration when choosing a publisher.â€œIt was absolutely the right decision to stay with Saraband for this book,â€ he says. â€œIn any authorâ€™s career thereâ€™s a time to test the waters with other publishers. This was my juncture, and I did get a really fantastic offer from one big London publisher and from another big indie. Saraband also made a great offer.â€œI tried to take the emotion out of making the decision, but with the long-standing relationship that we have and the amazing marketing plan they had for the book I knew we could work well together. They were collaborative about aspects like cover design, so in the end it was really a very easy decision to make. Itâ€™s so important to have a strong independent publishing sector and even though Saraband is now based in Manchester, I think that Sara Hunt, the publisher, still thinks of Saraband is essentially a Scottish publishing company.â€Working with a successful smaller publisher also meant that there was no pressure to become a â€œgenreâ€ author. There has been no pressure to follow up any of the books with more of the same. From a sort-of detective novel set in a small town in France, to a th-century murder story in the Highlands, then back to that small town in France and now s London.Â â€œIâ€™ve only acquired an agent relatively recently and I told them that all I really want to do is write books. I think it can make it dficult for publishersyouâ€™re not a brand in some way. I think there are some similarities between all my books. Thereâ€™s a familiarity of approach of how you express things and inevitably you bring your own sensibility to whatever the raw material is.â€Graeme is currently back in small town Franceand working on the final book of in the Gorski trilogy, but there are also plans to venture deep into Central Europe.As an English teacher, Graeme spent time living in France, Spain and the Czech Republic and itâ€™s his time in pre-stag heaven Prague that might well inform that journey further east.He agrees that location can be another crucial character in a book and as a writer thereâ€™s a tendency to be hyper-aware of surroundings.â€œAs a writer thatâ€™s a gt isnâ€™t it  I lived in Prague for a year and I learned some Czech, but not enough to have a serious conversation. This was back in , before the advent of cheap flights and at the time there werenâ€™t many foreigners living there.â€œIt was a really formative experience and so interesting to be in a place at the moment of genuine transition things were changing on a weekly basis. To get there I had to go to London to get a visa from the Czechoslovakian Embassy. The Iron Curtain had fallen of course, but a lot of the structures were still in place. Itâ€™s probably changed so much but in my mind are the winding medieval streets in winter. Dashing between bars, getting a little grog in each. Everything looks like an old sort of Sherlock Holmes film really.â€What he will write he says isnâ€™t even a half-formed idea and it might be a fictionalised central European destination but itâ€™s clear his memories of the time are vivid. â€œItâ€™s still in my imagination and Iâ€™ve just finished re-reading The Trial by Franz Kafka so itâ€™s at the forefront of my mind.â€For the moment, however, itâ€™s planning to get out and share the paperback of Case Study at events, including ato the Highlands for the Ullapool Book Festival in May. title: glasgow-council-apologises-role-connections-slave-trade
story: Councillor leader Susan Aitken put forward an amendment to offer an apology following a report which examined in detail the cityâ€™s connection and subsequent wealth from the transatlantic slave trade.The amendment to the report brought before the council was raised by Councillor Aitken to include an immediate apology and was supported and agreedÂ by the chamber.Read more:Â Eight Glasgow statues singled out for links to slave trade, report revealedCouncillor Aitken told the chamber the report could be the most signicant in the councilâ€™s term, adding: â€œIt uncovers and elucidates in greater detail than ever before a part of Glasgowâ€™s history that this city has often marginalised or downplayed. It can no longer be ignored and the amendment that I am moving today asks us to do three things to acknowledge, apologise and to act. We have long known much of the source of the wealth of which Glasgow was built. We knew but up until recently didnâ€™t think much about what it really meant and we brushed aside the voices trying to tell us.â€œIn our recent era when other cities were sincerely grappling with their role in chattel slavery, our city was still glorying it naming the Merchant City barely a decade before Liverpool issued an apology for the type of things we are her discussing today.â€œFollow the Atlantic slavery money trail and its tentacles reach into every corner of Glasgow. The predecessor organisation of this very council borrowed and invested money to the equivalent of millions of pounds that directly came from and contributed to chattel slavery. Itâ€™s clearÂ what this report tells is that the blood of trafficked and enslaved African people, their children and their childrenâ€™s children is built into the very bones of this city. Glasgowâ€™s history to the present day echoes to the crack of the plantation overseers lash. Chattel slavery stands as one of the most heinous crimes in human history and Glasgow was complicit and for that we apologise today, unreservedly, without excuses, justications or attempts at self-congratulation of the type we have too often employed in the past.â€Read more:Â  Glasgow street names and areas with links to slave tradeShe said many will ask what good an apology will do, adding that it canâ€™t change the past and no one alive today took part in chattel slavery.â€œMany who are alive today still live with the legacy of racism whose roots can be traced directly back to what was white supremacy codied in law and the countryâ€™s whose populations were stolen and enslaved suffer still. An apology tells them that finally we are trying to understand,â€ she added.The ammendment was seconded by Councillor Graham Campbell, chairman of the councils cross party working group on slavery, who said: "This is a historically unprecedented statement and I am in the position of being both able to support this ammendment to make this offer of an apology on behalf of the city, but also to partyly accept the apology on behalf of African and Caribbean descedants as the first one present in this chamber."Perhaps the  Lord Provosts mentioned in the report who got their wealth from ill gotten gains would never have anticipated someone like me would be here. Why are we remembering and what is the purpose of doing this  We have had organised forgetting of the record of Glasgows involvement in chattel slavery. We have now got the historic evidence and it is now up to us as citizens to see what we can do with that information - how we teach the legacy of chattel slavery.Â "Slavery and colonialism are the origins of the racism we face today - how people think, the stereotypes and prejudices are derived from that time."Councillor Campbell said the  Black Lives Matter protest shows that there is a racism problem in the city which is why measures have had to be taken. This apology is just a first step and is part of the journey not the end."Labour group leader, Councillor Malcolm Cunning said there had been decades of denial of the citys slave trade connections and that it was given little mention in the school books of the past.He said: "It has taken far tooÂ long to realise that deep-seated, interwoven legacy of slavery in Glasgow. We now need to say how do we go foward, what do we do now and how do we make our apology and acknowledgement in the st century."Greens Councillor Kim Long said they welcomed and supported the report, adding: "It is especiallyÂ important for us to note the impact and the leadership of the first black councillors elected to this chamber. It is crucial for us as a city to move from the stance of we didnt know, to we do know."The city council commissioned report, led by Dr Stephen Mullen, an academic historian with the University of Glasgow, singled out eight Glasgow statues of iniduals with connections to the slave trade.Â It added that gts from those linked to the trade amounted to more than Â£ million in todayâ€™s money, with a bequest that would amount to Â£m for the Mitchell Library in .The monuments to Colin Campbell, William Gladstone, John Moore, David Livingstone, James Oswald, Robert Peel Jnr, James Watt and King William III are all highlighted in the reportThe report also highlights  Glasgow streets and locations with connections to Atlantic slavery. These include Buchanan Street, named after Andrew Buchanan Jr, and Glassford Street, after tobacco lord John Glassford.Between  and ,  out of Â  lord provosts nominated to Glasgow Town Council had some connection to Atlantic slavery, and some sat in office whilst owning enslaved people.Â

title: sturgeon-seeks-total-control-scotlands-railways-scotrail-nationalised
story: The First Minister said it now wanted control of the infrastructure, which includes the tracks and signals, currently run by Network Rail.She spoke of the ultimate ambition as she dismissed claims that the new nationalised ScotRail will become "CalMac on wheels".The First Minister said that the move to public ownership is a "very signicant milestone" and "marksa new beginning for ScotRail".And she added: "Our commitment is clear. Weve invested nine billion pounds in the railway since ."We will continue to press for full devolution of rail powers including full devolution of Network Rail in Scotland so that we can then truly deliver the railway that Scotland wants and deserves."The services are to be run by a Scottish Government arms- company after the seven-year stint by Dutch state transport firm Abellio comes to an end.Ms Sturgeon told MSPs: "It provides an opportunity to modernise and deliver passenger services which are efficient, sustainable, safe, fit for the future, and which reflect the changing world we live in."Obviously, from tomorrow services will continue as normal. Its important that we provide reassurance and familiarity to passengers in the immediate term as we recover from the disruption and impact of the pandemic. Later this spring we will watch the national conversation offering rail staff, passengers and communities an opportunity to contribute to the future vision for Scotlands Railway and help shape this new beginning for Scotland."But Graham Simpson, the Scottish Conservatives shadow transport secretary questioned whether the rail service would become like the publicly run ferry service."We know the SNP is no good at running things, you just have to look at the ferries for that."So given that fiasco, rail passengers should be worried that NatRail will turn out to be CalMac on wheels."On Sunday, transport minister Jenny Gilruth was quoted as saying from day one, you might not necessarily see anything that looks dferent, but the major dference is accountability. Well Ms Gilruth obviously didnt get the memo that this government doesnt do accountability. So far, what we do know is that were going to have rising fares, service cuts and ticket office closures. What part of that is an improvement  "But Ms Sturgeon hit back: "This government of course, has already delivered signicant improvements on our railways and thats even before the railway comes into public ownershi as it will tomorrow."She then listed a series of towns and villages that had all connected to the rail network since  through the reversal of cuts.And said in the next three years five more will follow."Railway workers in England under the Tories face a pay freeze. A fair pay deal was delivered in October last year for ScotRail staff," she said. "And lastly, of course weve taken action to keep rail fares down. ScotRail fares are on average % cheaper than in those areas of the UK governed by the Conservatives."The debate came as RMT began holding a day of action calling on the Scottish Government to promote and expand all jobs, skills, services and ticket offices connected to the newly nationalised ScotRail.RMT members were due to gather outside Glasgow Queen Street station at noon, demanding that the new operator â€œdelivers for Scotlandâ€™s rail passengers, communities, and workersâ€.Ms Sturgeon added: "I think bringing Scotland to public ownership is a historic moment and I am delighted that it is happening under this government. "Abellio has been running the franchise since  but had its contract ended early amid criticism over cancellations and performance levels.All ScotRail staff will transfer to the new Scottish government-owned entity.A new company called ScotRail Trains Limited will run services from April , overseen by Scottish Rail Holdings Ltd, a new public body controlled by the Scottish Government.

title: oic shares countywide roadworks update

title: orcadian composer receives royal commission
story: An Orkney-born composer is royally chuffed to have been selected to help mark HM Queen#s Platinum Jubilee.Erland Cooper, who originally hails from Stromness, hasÂ been commissioned to create an original piece of music to soundtrack the floral transformation of The Tower of London.Entitled Superbloom, the forthcoming installation will celebrate  years of Queen Elizabeth II#s reign.The project is named after a rare and incredible natural phenomenon, where whole landscapes are miraculously transformed into sheets of vibrant flowers.A â€œsuperbloomâ€ occurs only once every few decades, when favourable weather patterns coincide and activate dormant seeds. The forthcoming #designed# Superbloom event will celebrate nature by turning one of Londonâ€™s most built-up areas into a blossoming, living flower field.Erlandhas been chosen to produce a gentle accompanying ambient soundscape for this urban garden, which will be played continuously through speakers, softening the noise of the city.He explained: #Music For Growing Flowers aims to enhance the Superbloomâ€™s emotional impact by rebalancing the dominant city noises and intertwining specic audio frequencies to uncover harmony in the most bustling environments.Since music itself is nothing more than vibrations, perhaps it will help us enter more deeply into this subtle appreciation of place, curiosity and calm.â€For his most recent album, the composer ed to his Orkney roots, actually planting the only existing Carves the Runes Then Be Content With Silence at a hidden location in the county.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: way to work is just the job for employers and candidates
story: advertorialWay To Work Is Just the Job for Employers and CandidatesMarch ,  at : amADVERTORIAL: The Way to Work initiative aims to get , unemployed workers into jobs by the end of June. Itâ€™s part of ambitious UK Government plans to turbo-charge our national recovery from COVID-. At the centre of this initiative is Jobcentre Plus.Jobcentre Plus has a long and successful track record of matching quality employers with quality candidates. Now, many highly-skilled people have found themselves unemployed for the first time, and are considering new roles in new sectors. Jobcentre Plus can quickly put companies in touch with candidates who can make a real dference to their businesses.We talk to employers and employees about how they have benefited from working with Jobcentre Plus. vw, px"  â€˜Working with Jobcentre Plus is a no brainerâ€™: Jordan, Contracts Manager, Elite Scaffolding, YeovilElite Scaffolding â€“ a family-owned business that is part of the Denholm Group, reached out to Jobcentre Plus in a bid to reach younger potential employees looking for an apprenticeship.#We initially approached the jobcentre, simply for advice and to askthey could place an ad on their system. We did not expect the extremely positive and proactive response we received from the jobcentre. The team was very helpful,# said Jordan.The support Elite got from the jobcentre was invaluable in streamlining and accelerating its recruitment process which would take up to five weeks.#Now, the jobcentre advertises our vacancies via a sector-based work academy.#Candidates attend a two-week course at Weston College, Yeovil, to gain their Scaffolding Operative Training Scheme and Health  Safety Certications, as well as to prepare for an interview. Now when we interview candidates, they already have a scaffold labourer trainee card and the basic knowledge and understanding of the scaffolding industry. Whatâ€™s more, all this support via the jobcentre comes without the additional fees of private agencies.#Out of seven candidates, six were offered jobs and five have remained with Elite which has  qualied operatives.#The process was seamless and effective, providing quality candidates who were keen to learn.#Working with the jobcentre is a no brainer! As well as alleviating the burden of interviews that donâ€™t progress into jobs, the savings in cost and time to get candidates suitably qualied are a bonus. It takes the pressure off our own resources and provides top quality candidates in the process.#â€˜Delightedâ€™: Simon, Employer Adviser, Yeovil JobCentreOnce approached by Elite Scaffolding, also based in Yeovil, he set up a meeting with one of its office managers and worked out a bespoke recruitment package.As part of the programme, he contacted the local Weston College and together they â€œbuiltâ€ the course content.At the end of the two-week course, six candidates were offered a place on the apprenticeship scheme at a starting salary of Â£,.#Elite had exhausted all other channels to recruit and were delighted with the outcome#, he said.Moreover Elite referred other local employers to the jobcentre and Simon is running another sector-based work academy with a local roofing company.#The jobcentre has an incredible pool of talent. One of my Elite Scaffolders said itâ€™s not just about finding me a job but changing my leâ€¦You certainly canâ€™t ask for better than that.#â€˜Welcomeâ€™: Samuel, JD Sports Apprentice, RochdaleSamuelâ€™s career got off to a flying start with a six-month placement through Jobcentre Plus at JD Sports.â€œI saw JD Sports was advertising and I thought Iâ€™d go for it because it was an administration role in a big company. Everything went through really quickly.#Continued the  year-old: â€œMy team at JD were great from day one. They made me feel welcome and supported me. I spent six months on the placement and I got paid, too. Itâ€™s a proper job which was exactly what I needed. Day to day, Iâ€™d look after anything from HR queries and issuing contracts to payroll and pension questions. It gave me a whole picture of what itâ€™s like to work in HR and Iâ€™ve been doing it ever since.â€œAfter six months, there was the option to stay on and Iâ€™m now doing an apprenticeship with JD. Once Iâ€™d finished with the placement I got started on a qualication â€“ CIPD level three in HR support. It was another perfect step for me and Iâ€™ve now been there for a year. title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An TÃ¬r, An CÃ nan, â€˜S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a personâ€™s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary â€“ not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection â€œa genuine product of the pastâ€ with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., â€˜blood is thicker than waterâ€™, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance â€“ strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly â€“ we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex GÃ idhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much â€“not more â€“ influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the GÃ idhealtachd connecting with the cultural â€˜myceliumâ€™ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream â€“ the carrying stream â€“ slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

story: With the countdown now on to Volunteersâ€™ Week , which runs from - June, Volunteer Now is calling on communities and businesses across Northern Ireland to get ready to honour local heroes by taking â€˜Time to Say Thanksâ€™ as part of a week-long programme of activity celebrating volunteering across the UK.   Now in its th year, Volunteersâ€™ Week sees charities, voluntary groups, social organisations, and volunteers themselves come together to recognise the incredible impact that volunteering has in communities, both locally and regionally. This yearâ€™s theme - â€˜A time to say thanksâ€™ â€“ encourages everyone to recognise the huge impact that people from all walks of le make on the lives of people and their communities when they volunteer. The week-long celebration, coinciding with the Queenâ€™s Platinum Jubilee, will include designated themed days showcasing the breadth and impact that dferent types of volunteering has played in local communities over the last  months. Each day is a chance to take the time to say thank you to volunteers across Northern Ireland â€“ and Volunteer Now is calling for all charities and volunteers to get involved. With around , formal volunteers carrying out work with designated organisations and , informal volunteers, volunteering plays a signicant role across the region. Each year, volunteers across Northern Ireland carry out work worth more than half a billion pounds and contribute pound million to the local economy. Voluntary organisations in Northern Ireland do work worth more than half a billion pounds a year. As the lead organisation for volunteering in Northern Ireland, Volunteer Now is leading the charge to put Volunteersâ€™ Week firmly on the community agenda, encouraging everyone to engage with the week-long programme of activity to say a collective â€˜thank youâ€™ to volunteers right across the region. title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220331newsfirmus announce another price hike this time by 16 31
story: Firmus energy has today announced an increase of .% from May ,  for gas customers in the Ten Towns area, impacting around , domestic customers. This increase will see the yearly gas bill of a typical household with a credit meter rise by about pound per year to pound,. Those customerswith a prepayment gas meterwill see costs increase by around pound per year to pound,. Raymond Gormley, Head of Energy Policy at the Consumer Council said: â€œIt is important that consumers are made aware that their domestic gas bills will stay high for at least the next year because the wholesale price that the companies pay for the gas continues to be much more expensive than the norm. Unfortunately heating oil prices are also very high, so regardless of the fuel we use, many of us will experience extreme pressure on our household budgets. This will further increase the numbers of people in fuel poverty, as many families may struggle to find the extra money they will now need to pay for heating. â€œAs the Winter   Emergency Fuel Payment Scheme ends today , we implore firmus energy, and the wider energy industry, to commit to financially supporting the continuation of a fuel hardship scheme in the coming financial year. For the longer term, it is clear that energy companies, policy makers, the Utility Regulator, charities and the Consumer Council must continue to work together to develop sustainable solutions to help support those in need as the problem of high energy prices will likely be with us for the foreseeable future.â€ Consumers who are struggling to pay their energy bills or struggling to pay to top-up their meter should contact their supplier directly for support. Consumers can also get in touch with the Consumer Council for free, independent advice by calling Freephone    or by emailingcontact@consumercouncil.org.uk. The Consumer Councilâ€™s websitehas a number of free resources includingSwitch On: A Guide for Home Energy Users,which helps consumers be more energy efficient at home, get the best from their electricity or gas supply, and save money. firmus energy customers in Greater Belfast and in the Gas to the West network area will not be impacted by this tarf change.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220401newselection set to be delayed due to ballot paper issues
story: The forthcoming election is set to be postponed for a fortnight due to insufficient amounts of the correct type of ballot paper, we understand. It is believed that the specic type of tree used to make the paper - Flora Plio â€“ has been in short supply in recent months. Paper production expert, Poppy Cox, explained why this specic type of tree was used for the production of ballot papers. â€œIt has a special waxy quality that prevents the mark you make on your ballot paper being rubbed out,â€ said Mrs Cox. â€œThat obviously adds an added level of security to the elections and stops people claiming that their ballot has been changed.â€ Alternatives are now being sought and the two week delay in the vote will hopefully allow for the ballot to be printed on a dferent type of paper. â€œIt is possible that we could see a special kind of foolscap being useda secure alternative canâ€™t be found,â€ Mrs Cox added. An official statement on the matter is due to be made at midday today .

title: sinn fein slammed for election launch at belfasts europa hotel which was repeatedly bombed by ira
story: Victims campaigner questions the choice of venue as Michelle Oâ€™Neill outlines her partyâ€™s stanceExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseSpeech: Sinn Feinâ€™s Michelle Oâ€™Neill addressing a party election event in Belfast. Credit :Sinn FeinGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA victimsâ€™ campaigner has questioned the use of the Europa Hotel as the setting for Sinn Feinâ€™s election launch, saying itâ€™s a venue the Provisional IRA â€œsystematically bombedâ€.On Tuesday, Michelle Oâ€™Neill gave a speech at the Great Victoria Street hotel, which was bombed  times during the Troubles.She outlined Sinn Feinâ€™s priorities ahead of the upcoming election including the cost of living crisis and â€œfiercely defendingâ€ the Good Friday Agreement.â€œThe facts are that the balance of power at Stormont has shted irreversibly and political unionism must come to terms with the fact the world is moving on fast,â€ Ms Oâ€™Neill said.â€œSo, while the DUP and the TUV are trying to take us backwards, our message is clear, we are only moving forward.â€Commenting on the choice of venue, Kenny Donaldson, spokesman for Innocent Victims United said: Sinn Fein clearly don#t do irony, to bleat on about upholding democracy at the very venue which the Provisional IRA systematically attacked again and again, making it the most bombed hotel in Europe is brazen to say the least.However, due to the intensity of the Provisional IRA#s bombing campaign â€”Â and that of other terrorists, few hotel venues across Northern Ireland have come away unscathed by the Troubles.â€Daily Headlines the hotel in which they met daring to ponticate about democracy and respecting the will of the people.â€œThere is nothing undemocratic about refusing to operate the Belfast Agreement structures which could foist a Sinn Fein First Minister upon Northern Ireland.â€œThe choice of venue for this republican jamboree underscores the fact that no unionist should ever agree to take up the position of deputy to a Sinn Fein First Minister.â€œYet just weeks out from the election both the DUP and UUP are dodging this vital question.Will they act as bridesmaid to Michelle O#Neill  Why is there reluctance to be open and honest with the public on this point â€The DUP#s Gordon Lyons said Sinn Fein#s election launch demonstrates their priority lies on holding a border poll rather than on helping families or rebuilding Northern Irelandâ€™s economy.The party#s director of elections said: Sinn Fein#s rally was a show of strength for a border poll.â€œWhilst the DUP has a five-point plan to build a better future for Northern Ireland, Sinn Fein wants to win the election to implement their plan for a border poll.â€œThere is a clear choice on offer to people whether they want a future focused on fixing our health system, tackling the cost of living crisis and replacing the protocol, or one fixated on a isive border poll.â€œWhen Michelle O#Neill talks about making history, we know it isn#t record levels of investment into our hospitals she is referring to. Now is not the time for ision and uncertainty.That is why this election is so important.Sinn Fein has been contacted for comment.Speaking at an election launch, Ms Oâ€™Neill said thatÂ Sinn Fein will defend but not renegotiate the Good Friday Agreement.The former Deputy FirstÂ Minister said those who hanker for the past need to realise that there is no going back, only forward.Sinn Fein#s Stormont leader also described the DUP#s collapse of theÂ Executive as political vandalism, although her own party also brought Stormont down in the same Assembly mandate.She said: When the Assembly, Executive and North South Ministerial Council were restored in January  it was with a shared commitment to deliver the public services, societal reforms and future that our people need and deserve.It was ambitious to form a five-party coalition Executive, but it was achieved, getting us back to genuine power-sharing, and thankfully so, because while everyone knew there would be challenges ahead, no one could have predicted that in only a matter of weeks that our Executive would be dealing with a global pandemic that would have such devastating impacts on every part of society, community and people#s lives and livelihoods.It is to the credit of all ministers from across the five parties that they responded and have worked with a unity of purpose, and unity of leadership for the past two years.This is what the public want to see more of â€” co-operation and delivery.Ms O#Neill added:Â Sinn Fein will be defending, not renegotiating the Good Friday Agreement now, or in the time ahead.Ms
